title: Les Shirley Park
listingDescription: On January 8, 1806, while exploring the area around what is known today the city of Cannon Beach, Oregon, Captain William Clark, a handful of men from the Corps of Discovery found, and the group’s native guide found themselves on a stretch of beach in search of a beached whale, hoping to bolster their dwindling supplies. Upon finding the whale, little flesh was left on its skeleton, the usable parts already having been harvested by the local people.
tags: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail)
Lewis and Clark National Historical Park
bodyText:
On January 8, 1806, while exploring the area around what is known today the city of Cannon Beach, Oregon, Captain William Clark, a handful of men from the Corps of Discovery found, and the group’s native guide found themselves on a stretch of beach in search of a beached whale, hoping to bolster their dwindling supplies. Upon finding the whale, little flesh was left on its skeleton, the usable parts already having been harvested by the local people. Disheartened, the men returned to a small Tillamook village of five houses that they had passed earlier that day, where the people were processing whale blubber.

After purchasing some whale oil and fish from the villagers, Clark shot a raven and gull with a small rifle and, after a meal, the explorers crossed the creek and set up camp. Some of the Tillamook men came to smoke with the captain, but their visit was interrupted by a loud commotion from across the creek. Concerned, Clark, his men, and the Tillamook visitors discovered that Private Hugh McNeal was missing. Clark describes the event in his journal, saying:

“…I Suspected perhaps Some of my party was over after the Squars, by exemening found that McNeal was not in Camp, 〈I was〉 my guide who Staid with me told me Some body throat was Cut. I emediately Sent Serjt Pryor & 〈4〉 2 men across for McNeal, they Soon returned haveing met the person I was anxious to find out the Cause of the allarm, McNeal Said that a man envited him to go across and get Some fish, locked arms of which he Contd to hold he took him into a lodge and the woman gave him a Small piec the man then invited him to another, the woman of the lodge puled his blanket, & Sent out a Squar to hollow across, to inform of Something which ald. [alarmed?] McNeal I Sent over Sergt. Pryor to Know the Cause of the allarm which he was informed that a Plot was laid to kill McNeal for his Blanket & Clothes by this Indian who was from another Villg at Some distance, and that She had attempted to Stop McNeal & findeing She Could not that She then allarmed the men, Several of the mans Band was with me who imedeately Cleared out, 2 men Came over & Slept at my feet. I kept a guard & Sentinel all night…”  

Today, the location of Clark’s campsite and the event that came to be known as “McNeal’s Folly” is encompassed within a small local park, known as Les Shirley Park, situated at the northern end of the city of Cannon Beach. Here, visitors will find picnic areas, access to the seashore at Cannon Beach, salt marshes, and wetlands. You can find more information at Les Shirley Park | City of Cannon Beach Oregon (cannon-beach.or.us)
audioDescription: Les Shirley Park features many picturesque spots for exploring or picnicking encompassing 65 acres. The park features access to a rocky beach along the Pacific Ocean, salt marshes full of tall grass and muddy water, and similarly described wetlands.

title: Lewis & Clark State Historic Site (Camp Dubois)
listingDescription: To tell visitors the story of the Camp River Dubois and the newly formed Corps of Discovery, the 14,000-square-foot visitor’s center presents the often-untold story of the Illinois portion of the Expedition. Construction of the center began in October 2000 in an area similar to that of the original Camp River Dubois on the south side of the Wood River, where the men of the Corps lived from December 1803 to May 1804.

images.credit: NPS
images.altText: large keelboat
images.title: Lewis & Clark State Historic Site, IL
images.caption: Large keelboat inside Lewis and Clark State Historic Site in Illinois.

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
To tell visitors the story of the Camp River Dubois and the newly formed Corps of Discovery, the 14,000-square-foot visitor’s center presents the often-untold story of the Illinois portion of the Expedition.  Construction of the center began in October 2000 in an area similar to that of the original Camp River Dubois on the south side of the Wood River, where the men of the Corps lived from December 1803 to May 1804.

Six galleries discuss the preparation phase of the Corps, including the information and knowledge gathered about the land west of the Mississippi River, and the expectations and anticipations of the newly formed Corps.  Everyone enjoys seeing the 55-foot, full-scale cut-away keelboat which demonstrates how the men handled packing the hundreds of bundles, boxes, and barrels of goods and supplies.  Outside stands a small replica fort, similar in structure to the original, which gives visitors an idea of what life was like on the frontier for this small military unit. 

Lewis & Clark Historic Site is near today’s confluence of the Missouri River, which can be best seen from the top of the nearby 180-foot-tall Confluence Tower.  However, due to changes in the course of both the Mississippi and Missouri Rivers over the past 200 years, the actual location of Camp River Dubois cannot be accurately pinpointed.  It’s often believed that the original site is now either under the main channel of the Mississippi, or even on the western side of the river, in today’s Missouri. 

The Lewis & Clark Historic Site is open from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., Wednesday through Sunday. The address is One Lewis and Clark Trail, Hartford, Illinois.  For more information call 618-251-5811 or go to www.campdubois.com.
audioDescription: Inside of a visitor center. Wooden keelboat with oars. Interpretive panels in the background.
passportStampLocationDescription: Stamp located inside the visitor center.
managedByOrg: Illinois Department of Natural Resources, Division of Historic Preservation

title: Lewis & Clark Boat House and Museum
listingDescription: Travel to St. Charles, Missouri and you’ll feel like you’ve stepped back in time to the early 19th century. The original state capital of Missouri, the picturesque town is filled with living history. Located about 25 miles northwest of downtown St. Louis, St. Charles played a significant role in the Lewis and Clark story. One of the highest ranked attractions in St. Charles is the Lewis & Clark Boat House and Museum, located right along the Missouri River.

images.altText: A large, two-story structure is shown. The lower level is constructed of stone, with two large arche
images.title: Lewis & Clark Boat House and Museum

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Travel to St. Charles, Missouri and you’ll feel like you’ve stepped back in time to the early 19th century.  The original state capital of Missouri, the picturesque town is filled with living history.  Located about 25 miles northwest of downtown St. Louis, St. Charles played a significant role in the Lewis and Clark story.

One of the highest ranked attractions in St. Charles is the Lewis & Clark Boat House and Museum, located right along the Missouri River.  In an impressive two-story building, the lower level is home to the full-size replica keelboat and two pirogues of the Lewis and Clark Discovery Expedition, a nationally recognized group of re-enactors of the Corps.  This dedicated group of historians provide ongoing appearances and demonstrations throughout the area to promote the Expedition and living history.  

Building the three boats required over 16,000 volunteer hours. Glenn Bishop initially spearheaded this immense project of constructing the boats. His vision continues to be realized today with re-enactments featuring the magnificently, hand-crafted, and highly unique fleet.  The Keelboat and two pirogues have been showcased in several films, documentaries and an upcoming televised miniseries.  When the boats are not appearing in events or re-enactments, they are on display at the Boat House. 

On the second floor is the Museum and Visitors’ Shop.  Formed in 1985, the educational Museum provides visitors the opportunity to explore the Lewis & Clark Expedition, Native American displays, various Missouri River habitats, and natural discoveries the Corps encountered during the journey. The museum’s artwork, "Missouri River Walk," is the largest indoor mural in the state.

Classes, private presentations, and tour-group talks are conducted in the classroom area and when not in use an award-winning film is shown throughout the day.  Adjacent to the Boat House is Bishop’s Landing with its huge sculpture of Lewis, Clark, and Seaman. 

Unique items for all ages are available in the Visitors’ Shop featuring a wide selection of books of all reading levels. Titles include those related to Lewis & Clark, Native Americans, general history, local interest, and nature.

The first Missouri State Capitol State Historic Site and the historic town of St. Charles are both easily walkable from our site.
  • Learn more about the boathouse 
  • Watch a short video overview of the musem
audioDescription: Three story structure. Bottom floor is open and made of stone. Top two floors are vertical wood slats, windows are surrounded by green shutters.
passportStampLocationDescription: Passport stamp located inside the museum.
managedByOrg: Lewis & Clark Boat House and Museum

title: Lewis & Clark Confluence Tower
listingDescription: In the village of Hartford, Illinois, the Lewis & Clark Confluence Tower rises an impressive 150 feet above the confluence of the Mississippi and Missouri rivers, the two longest rivers in all North America. Built to commemorate the 200th anniversary of the beginning of the Lewis & Clark Expedition, construction on the monument was completed on May 14, 2010.

images.credit: "Confluence Tower and Lewis and Clark Memorial" by ILMO JOE is licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 2.0
images.altText: Two white spires stretch into the sky as visitors walk between them
images.title: Lewis & Clark Confluence Tower
images.caption: Lewis & Clark Confluence Tower

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
In the village of Hartford, Illinois, the Lewis & Clark Confluence Tower rises an impressive 150 feet above the confluence of the Mississippi and Missouri rivers, the two longest rivers in all North America. Built to commemorate the 200th anniversary of the beginning of the Lewis & Clark Expedition, construction on the monument was completed on May 14, 2010.

How does it relate to the Lewis & Clark expedition, you ask? Well, in many ways, it was the first step on what would become known as the Lewis & Clark Expedition. In December of 1803, Meriwether Lewis and William Clark established camp at Wood River, otherwise known as Camp Dubois. Located along the Mississippi River between St. Louis and the modern-day Confluence Tower, the camp served as the winter quarters for the two men and those who joined them on their expedition. Here, they spent the winter gathering supplies and recruiting other intrepid explorers from St. Louis. Then, in May of 1804, the group embarked on their historic journey westward from the confluence of the Mississippi and Missouri rivers.

For those wishing to get a bird’s eye view of the area, the Confluence Tower has observations decks at the 50, 100, and 150-foot marks, and all three levels are accessible by either stairs or elevator. Exhibits focusing on Lewis and Clark and the importance of the Missouri-Mississippi Confluence can be found on every level. Guests can also request a short, guided tour that ends with a trip to the highest level of the structure. On particularly clear days, parts of St. Louis and the Gateway Arch can be seen from the upper decks.
audioDescription: Two white spires stretch over 150 feet into the air. Observation decks stretch between them every 50 feet. The left spire has the word "Lewis" above a mural, and "Clark" appears above a scene on the right one.

title: Lewis & Clark Interpretive Experience
listingDescription: Journey back to the early 1800s and retrace the footsteps of Lewis & Clark as they journeyed through Montana. See what the Corps of Discovery saw as they traveled by foot over scenic mountains and by boat through the clear waters. Follow an etching of the Missouri River along one side of the pedestrian plaza and the Yellowstone along the other side, experiencing several of the journey’s highlights along the way.
tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Journey back to the early 1800s and retrace the footsteps of Lewis & Clark as they journeyed through Montana. See what the Corps of Discovery saw as they traveled by foot over scenic mountains and by boat through the clear waters. Follow an etching of the Missouri River along one side of the pedestrian plaza and the Yellowstone along the other side, experiencing several of the journey’s highlights along the way.

This permanent outdoor exhibit located at the Great Northern Town Center is a cooperative project with Lewis & Clark Trail Commission. Visitors to this exhibit will enjoy and learn about 19 historical sites from Montana’s Lewis & Clark Trail such as the Gates of the Mountains, Pompeys Pillar, Great Falls/Portage and the Three Forks of the Missouri. Enormous boulders, for example, form the Interpretive Exhibit’s version of Pompeys Pillar, complete with bison prints and a replica of Clark’s signature. The easy interpretive signage will guide you on your journey of Lewis & Clark’s Montana Experience.

The outdoor exhibit is surrounded by restaurants, a carousel, a coffee shop, a children’s science museum, a cinema, shopping and the Best Western Premier Great Northern Hotel.
audioDescription: Outdoor exhibits consisting of 19 historical sites from the Montana portion of the Lewis and Clark Trail. Statues, interpretive panels, water features, paved walkways, murals, landscaped plants.

title: Lewis & Clark KATY Trailhead Plaza
listingDescription: Jefferson City now has many sites to recognize its connection to Lewis and Clark, including a monument that sits next to the Missouri State Capitol in Jefferson City, known officially as the Lewis and Clark Monument at the Katy Trailhead Plaza.

images.credit: "Lewis & Clark Statues - Jefferson City, MO" by Robert Stinnett is licensed under CC BY 2.0
images.altText: Five bronze statues of a waterfall feature made of stacked sandstone shale
images.title: Lewis & Clark Statue at Katy Plaza
images.caption: The statues at KATY Plaza

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Jefferson City now has many sites to recognize its connection to Lewis and Clark, including a monument that sits next to the Missouri State Capitol in Jefferson City, known officially as the Lewis and Clark Monument at the Katy Trailhead Plaza.

The monument is located near the corner of Jefferson Street and Capitol Avenue on the capitol grounds overlooking the Jefferson Landing Historic Site and the Missouri River. Dedicated on June 4, 2008 the plaza includes Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, York, George Druillard (French-Canadian-Shawnee hunter and interpreter) and Seaman (Lewis’ Newfoundland dog). Besides these main characters, items such as a journal, telescope, guns and hats are portrayed within the monument. The sculpture commemorates the date of June 4, 1804 when the Corps of Discovery encamped in the area, which eventually became the state capitol.
audioDescription: Statues of Meriwether Lewis, William Clark, Clark's servant York, George Druillard, Lewis' dog Seaman above a flagstone waterfall feature. Trees, green park rounds, landscaped plants.

title: Lewis & Clark Visitor Center at Gavins Point Dam
listingDescription: In August of 1804, explorers Meriwether Lewis and William Clark passed near Calumet Bluff in what is known today as Crofton, Nebraska as they headed westward. Since they were traveling through Yankton Sioux territory, they intended to meet with the tribe to inform them that the United States now presided over their land. The meeting took place on August 29th on top of Calumet bluff, where the expedition had established camp.

images.credit: "Lewis & Clark Visitors Center near Gavins Point Dam" by ali eminov is licensed under CC BY-NC 2.0
images.altText: Brick walkway leading towards a beige building with a tree in front of it
images.title: Lewis & Clark Visitor Center, Nebraska
images.caption: Lewis & Clark Visitor Center at Gavins Point Dam

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
In August of 1804, explorers Meriwether Lewis and William Clark passed near Calumet Bluff in what is known today as Crofton, Nebraska as they headed westward. Since they were traveling through Yankton Sioux territory, they intended to meet with the tribe to inform them that the United States now presided over their land. The meeting took place on August 29th on top of Calumet bluff, where the expedition had established camp. During the gathering, Lewis gave their leaders various presents as a form of peacekeeping.  

Today, the Lewis & Clark Visitor Center rests atop Calumet Bluff, providing a spectacular view of Gavins Point Dam and Lewis & Clark Lake. Here, visitors can learn about the history of the region and the Lewis & Clark expedition through a variety of indoor and outdoor exhibits, as well as peruse the gift shop and bookstore at their leisure. 

For more information about the Lewis & Clark Visitor Center at Gavins Point Dam, call 402-667-2546.
audioDescription: The Lewis & Clark Visitor Center is a large building approximately 16-19 feet tall with a stone exterior and large windows. The building sits upon a hill overlooking the Gavins Point Dam and Lewis & Clark Lake below. On the inside, many different informational exhibits about Lewis and Clark are available, as well as a gift shop and bookstore.

quickFacts.value: The site where Lewis and Clark met with the Yankton Sioux

title: Lewis & Clark and the Kanza
listingDescription: Discover the original home of the Kanza Indians in the state that bears their name and the location of the first celebration of Independence Day in the West. Independence Creek: Lewis & Clark Historic Site is the campsite where the Lewis & Clark expedition spent the night on July 4, 1804. The area covers 13.5 acres of native grasses & wildflowers. Today, a re-created Kanza Earthlodge is connected to the Atchison Riverfront by a hiking/biking trail.
tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Discover the original home of the Kanza Indians in the state that bears their name and the location of the first celebration of Independence Day in the West.

Independence Creek: Lewis & Clark Historic Site is the campsite where the Lewis & Clark expedition spent the night on July 4, 1804. The area covers 13.5 acres of native grasses & wildflowers. Today, a re-created Kanza Earthlodge is connected to the Atchison Riverfront by a hiking/biking trail.

Located five miles north of Atchison’s Main Street, this site may be reached by car or by hiking/biking trail. The site has reestablished the prairie as seen by the Corps of Discovery and encompasses a stretch of Independence Creek referred to by Captain William Clark in his July 4, 1804 journal entry. A pedestrian bridge completes the 5-mile trail link to the Atchison Riverfront.
audioDescription: grass-covered earth lodge, split rail fence, interpretive panels, grasses, wildflowers.

title: Lewis Buys Seaman
listingDescription: Meriwether Lewis purchased his dog, Seaman, near here. Seaman was the only non-human permanent member of the expedition.

images.credit: Senator John Heinz History Center
images.altText: Drawing of the city of Pittsburgh from 1819.
images.title: Lewis Buys Seaman
images.caption: Illustration of the city of Pittsburgh on a decorative plate. Steamship on the river in the foregrou

tags: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail
bodyText:
Around the time he departed Pittsburgh in late August 1803, Meriwether Lewis recruited crew members.  

One of those new recruits may have been a dog. 

Lewis purchased a Newfoundland dog in September 1803 for $20 (roughly $500 in 2022 dollars). Why? 

Newfoundland dogs are known to be intelligent, hard-working, loyal, and well-tempered animals, as well as good hunters and swimmers. This meant Seaman could handle a mostly river-bound journey and help with hunting, all while being good-natured.

Seaman especially loved to chase squirrels in the river. Maybe he loved it even more because of how much his human liked eating them. Day after day on the Ohio River, Lewis saw squirrels swimming across the river—almost always from the north to the south shore, he observed. Most days, Seaman would hop in the river and chase after a few.

After he swam his heart out, Seaman would return to the boat, sopping wet. Maybe Lewis would have to help hoist him back onto the boat, or maybe he’d jump himself, heavy fur and all. He may have been proud to please his human with a squirrel offering, and perhaps excited to hop back again into the river and go chase some more.  

About this article: This article is part of a series called “Pivotal Places: Stories from the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail.”
audioDescription: Low-lying, wooded islands in the middle of the Ohio River. The banks of the river are also covered in trees and rise on either side of the wide river.
managedByOrg: Ohio River Islands National Wildlife Refuge

title: Lewis and Clark Commemorative Trail
listingDescription: Follow in the footsteps of Lewis and Clark along this 8 mile commemorative trail in North East Oregon. Journey next to the mighty Columbia River while viewing majestic osprey and bald eagles flying overhead. Enjoy amazing views of geological features such as the Wallula Gap and basalt bluffs that tell a story of floods that helped shape this area.
tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Follow in the footsteps of Lewis and Clark along this 8 mile commemorative trail in North East Oregon. Journey next to the mighty Columbia River while viewing majestic osprey and bald eagles flying overhead. Enjoy amazing views of geological features such as the Wallula Gap and basalt bluffs that tell a story of floods that helped shape this area.

The terrain of the trail is generally flat and wide with short sections of narrow, moderately steep grades where the trail diverts around washouts. Very few areas of shade along the trail.

Trail can be accessed at 3 different locations: McNary Beach Recreation Area, Hat Rock State Park, and Warehouse Beach Habitat Management Unit. Equestrian parking available at all 3 locations with Warehouse Beach being the primary staging area.

Trail distance from McNary Beach to Hat Rock State Park: 6 miles

Trail distance from Hat Rock State Park to Warehouse Beach: 2 miles

Restroom facilities available at McNary Beach, Hat Rock State Park, and Warehouse Beach. No potable water available.
audioDescription: Columbia River, grassland prarie, basalt bluffs, flat and wide trail with moderately steep grade.

title: Lewis and Clark Enter into Louisiana Purchase
listingDescription: In 1803, France sold the United States hundreds of thousands of acres of land west of the Mississippi River—lands that belonged to many Indigenous people.

images.credit: Library of Congress
images.altText: Section of an 1814 map showing the Missouri River and several large settlements of Indigenous people
images.title: Louisiana Purchse
images.caption: The land that France deeded to the United States in the Louisiana Purchase was not empty.

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
European powers based their claims to the Louisiana Territory on a European legal theory called the “Doctrine of Discovery.” The first European nation to “discover” lands unknown to them could then lay claim to those lands.  

The Doctrine of Discovery minimized the right of Indigenous people to their own lands. It only allowed Indigenous communities to retain a so-called “native title.” This meant they could occupy and use, but not own, their own homelands. It still required Europeans to negotiate treaties with Indigenous leaders to fully take over their land. 

The French first claimed the territory west of the Mississippi River in 1682 and called it La Louisiane after King Louis XIV. French settlers knew about Indigenous nations who had lived, farmed, and hunted near great cities like Cahokia for millennia, but according to the rules that the European leaders wrote, Indigenous claims were not as valid as those of these new arrivals.  

France, Britain, Spain, and eventually, the new United States of America, vied for and divided up this land that had been occupied by many people since time immemorial. This back and forth culminated in 1803, when the United States agreed to pay France $15 million for 818,000-square-miles of territory west of the Mississippi River that France claimed. With this purchase complete, the U.S. government could negotiate directly with Indigenous communities for their lands. 

One of President Thomas Jefferson’s main goals for the Lewis and Clark Expedition was to establish contact with as many Indigenous people as they could and understand “the extent & limits of their possessions.” Once armed with this information, the United States could take these lands, either through treaty or through force.  

For Indigenous people west of the Mississippi River, the Louisiana Purchase was the beginning of a hundred years of land loss, forced relocation, and threats to traditional lifeways.

About this article: This article is part of series called “Pivotal Places: Stories from the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail.”
audioDescription: Flat, open grassy area bounded by open river waters on three sides. Bridges visible in the distance.

quickFacts.value: This is the location of the confluence of the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers. Meriwether Lewis and William Clark passed through here in 1803 on their way into lands ceded to the United States from France as part of the Louisiana Purchase.

title: Lewis and Clark Heritage Trail
listingDescription: The Lewis and Clark Heritage Trail—also known as The Columbia River Dike Trail—follows the Columbia River from Steamboat Landing Park to the border of the Steigerwald Lake National Wildlife Refuge. This park will soon be aligned with the Washougal Waterfront Park and trail creating a long connected walking trail both into Camas and Washougal.

images.credit: "Steamboat Landing Park" by Diesel Dan is licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 2.0
images.altText: Fishermen along a dock stretching out into the water.
images.title: Steamboat Landing Park
images.caption: The trail starts at Steamboat Landing Park

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
The Lewis and Clark Heritage Trail—also known as The Columbia River Dike Trail—follows the Columbia River from Steamboat Landing Park to the border of the Steigerwald Lake National Wildlife Refuge. This park will soon be aligned with the Washougal Waterfront Park and trail creating a long connected walking trail both into Camas and Washougal. Along the way, trail-goers will enjoy views of the river and Mt. Hood, wildlife, beautiful resting areas and historical interpretive signage. The heritage trail is also home to many charity runs and walking events each year.

The trail parallels Cottonwood Beach and is named for Lewis and Clark, who camped there in 1806. Walkers may enjoy taking a partial loop back on the Gibbons Creek Wildlife Trail in the adjacent wildlife area.
audioDescription: Packed Gravel trail, 12-foot wide

title: Lewis and Clark Historic Marker at Steamboat Landing
listingDescription: One week into the long journey home in April 1806, The Lewis and Clark Expedition were warned by the Native people that spring salmon had not yet returned so food was scarce traveling east. With that news, they decided to establish a provisional camp at this location along the shore of the Columbia River. They hunted elk, bear and deer and dried the meat that would last them until they arrived at the Nez Perce village in present-day Idaho.
tags: lewis and clark national historic trail

title: Lewis and Clark Interpretive Center (North Dakota)
listingDescription: The Corps of Discovery lived at Fort Mandan for about 22 weeks during the winter of 1804-05. So it seems fitting that today an impressive Lewis and Clark Interpretive Center shares the story of the Expedition in central North Dakota, in the vicinity of the Native villages. In Washburn, North Dakota, the Interpretive Center explains how this area was once the crossroads of culture and commerce on the Northern Plains.

images.credit: North Dakota Parks and Recreation
images.altText: large visitor center building with green roof
images.title: Lewis and Clark Interpretive Center (ND)
images.caption: Lewis and Clark Interpretive Center in Washburn, ND

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
The Corps of Discovery lived at Fort Mandan for about 22 weeks during the winter of 1804-05.  So it seems fitting that today an impressive Lewis and Clark Interpretive Center shares the story of the Expedition in central North Dakota, in the vicinity of the Native villages. 

In Washburn, North Dakota, the Interpretive Center explains how this area was once the crossroads of culture and commerce on the Northern Plains.  Here lived the Mandan and Hidatsa peoples who were visited for generations by traders, trappers, and explorers such as Lewis and Clark. 

The Center includes large permanent galleries which explain the many facets of life on the Plains. Here you’ll learn about the lives of the Native peoples, the explorers, and the traders.  Two galleries feature rotating art and history exhibits. 

A short drive away stands a full-size replica of Fort Mandan, where you can get a first-hand experience of what the Corps of Discovery’s life was like.  

What you’re sure to enjoy the most is the Center’s nationally certified interpretive staff.  The team works hard to make your visit a remarkable learning experience that captures your every sense. 

While the Interpretive Center is primarily self-guided, there are both self-guided or interpreter-led tours of the Fort, during the season. And special events are scheduled throughout the year – check their website for details. 

Washburn is approximately 40 miles north of Bismarck.
audioDescription: Large wood framed building with green trim. Large statues out front.
passportStampLocationDescription: Stamp is located in the visitor center.
managedByOrg: State Historical Society of North Dakota

title: Lewis and Clark Interpretive Pavilion at White Cloud
listingDescription: The Lewis and Clark Interpretive Pavilion at White Cloud, Kansas, describes the expedition’s passage through the area in 1804 and then again in 1806, the northern reaches of Kaw or Kansa tribal territory. There is a stone marker nearby for the bicentennial as well. The Iowa tribe was assigned this land as a reservation in 1836 after it had been ceded by the Kansa. This hollow became the favored hunting ground for its head chief, White Cloud II.
tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
The Lewis and Clark Interpretive Pavilion at White Cloud, Kansas, describes the expedition’s passage through the area in 1804 and then again in 1806, the northern reaches of Kaw or Kansa tribal territory. There is a stone marker nearby for the bicentennial as well. The Iowa tribe was assigned this land as a reservation in 1836 after it had been ceded by the Kansa. This hollow became the favored hunting ground for its head chief, White Cloud II. After the Iowa ceded this location in 1854, the town was established in 1857 and named in honor of the Iowa chief White Cloud. The town was a bustling one, as the site of a steamboat landing, the oldest opera house west of the Missouri R., and it was where the inventor of the Gatling gun lived.

The national Piggy Bank movement was started here, and it is considered the birthplace of the piggy bank. The movie “Paper Moon” was filmed in part here as well. The historic general store and other buildings are being renovated in this beautiful little town with its famous Four State Lookout. The famous White Cloud Flea Market is held on two weekends: Memorial Day and Labor Day.
audioDescription: A paved ramp with a wooden handrail leads up to a semicircular covered observation pavilion that overlooks the Missouri River. Interpretive panels tell the story of the Lewis and Clark Expedition's passage through the area. Grass and trees surround it. The structure is adjacent to a gravel parking lot.

title: Lewis and Clark Monument at Rainbow Point, Council Bluffs
listingDescription: High above the Missouri River valley, looking west toward the Omaha metropolitan area, is Lewis and Clark Monument Park at Rainbow Point on the northern edge of Council Bluffs, Iowa.

images.altText: : One of the stone monuments stands in a paved area
images.title: Lewis and Clark Monument Rainbow Point
images.caption: Lewis and Clark Monument Park

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
High above the Missouri River valley, looking west toward the Omaha metropolitan area, is Lewis and Clark Monument Park at Rainbow Point on the northern edge of Council Bluffs, Iowa.  

Dedicated in 1936 to honor the Corps of Discovery, the park has a small observation deck and two large commemorative stone markers, quarried from the Folsom Quarry in Vermont and created by sculptor Harry E. Stinson and architect George L. Horner.  The images and text on the markers explain Lewis and Clark’s meeting with local Oto and Missouri Indians.  (The actual site of the meeting took place on the west side of the Missouri about 10 miles north of Omaha near today’s Fort Calhoun, Nebraska.)

The monument stands atop a ridge of the Loess Hills, which run along much of the western edge of Iowa.  For this reason, mountain bikers enjoy the challenging route through the heavy woods of the park, hikers appreciate the nearby trails, and aerial enthusiasts love the panoramic view of planes landing at Omaha’s Eppley Airfield just across the Missouri. 

You’ll find Lewis and Clark Monument Park at 19962 Monument Road in Council Bluffs.
audioDescription: the park has a small observation deck and two large commemorative stone markers, quarried from the Folsom Quarry in Vermont and created by sculptor Harry E. Stinson and architect George L. Horner. The images and text on the markers explain Lewis and Clark’s meeting with local Oto and Missouri Indians.

title: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Interpretive Center (Great Falls, MT)
listingDescription: Overlooking the Missouri in Great Falls, MT is the impressive Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Interpretive Center, administered by the USDA Forest Service. In this beautiful 25,000-square-foot building, visitors are fully immersed in the legendary story of Lewis and Clark.

images.altText: The life-size diorama of several members of the Corps pulling a huge dugout canoe up a steep hill.
images.title: Exhibit at Interpretive Center

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Any trip to Great Falls, Montana is sure to be filled with plenty of Lewis and Clark adventures.  It was here over a period of a month in the summer of 1805, the men of the Corps did the almost unthinkable – an 18-mile portage of all the supplies, instruments, personal belongings, food, and canoes around the five intimidating falls of the Missouri River.  

Today, overlooking the Missouri is the equally impressive Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Interpretive Center, administered by the USDA Forest Service.  In this beautiful 25,000-square-foot building, visitors are fully immersed in the legendary story of Lewis and Clark.  The Center not only chronicles the portage journey of the Expedition, it explains the Corps’ important experiences with Plains and Northwest Indians.  You’ll learn details of the plants and animals that Expedition members documented and you’ll feel the Expedition’s disappointment at the impossibility of a Northwest Passage water route.

Begin your indoor journey with one of two video presentations in the theater-style auditorium.  Then join a ranger for a guided program or explore on your own through two levels of interpretive displays and exhibits.  The self-guided exhibit hall’s centerpiece is the two-story diorama of the portage of the Missouri River’s five great falls.  You can even test your strength pulling a boat against the Missouri’s current.  Enhance your journey with a 30-minute audio tour available in multiple languages, or choose the optional actor-portrayed, 45-minute audio of William Clark and George Shannon reminiscing 20 years after the expedition -- available in English only. 

But save some time to venture outdoors with a ranger, or explore several trails on your own.  Enjoy scenic overlooks and native landscaping.  And educational displays along the trails focus on the important roles landscape and wildlife played in the Lewis and Clark Expedition’s time in Montana.  Don’t miss the short trail to neighboring Giant Springs State Park, site of another historic landmark along the Lewis and Clark Trail.

Before you depart, be sure to check out the Portage Cache store for a wide-variety of gifts, books, toys, and other Expedition-related items. 

The Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Interpretive Center is located at 4201 Giant Springs Road in Great Falls.  For current fees, hours, and information, go to: 
https://www.fs.usda.gov/recarea/hlcnf/recarea/?recid=61458
audioDescription: Begin your indoor journey with one of two video presentations in the theater-style auditorium.  Then join a ranger for a guided program or explore on your own through two levels of interpretive displays and exhibits.  The self-guided exhibit hall’s centerpiece is the two-story diorama of the portage of the Missouri River’s five great falls.  You can even test your strength pulling a boat against the Missouri’s current.  Enhance your journey with a 30-minute audio tour available in multiple languages, or choose the optional actor-portrayed, 45-minute audio of William Clark and George Shannon reminiscing 20 years after the expedition -- available in English only.

title: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center - "This Trail is 4900 Miles Long"
listingDescription: "This Trail is 4900 Miles Long" interpretive banner. Part of the audio tour for the Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center in Omaha, Nebraska.

images.credit: NPS Photo
images.altText: A banner showing mountains, a setting sun, and two cyclists on a trail
images.title: This Trail is 4900 Miles LECL
images.caption: This banner is one of many interpretive signs you'll see in the garden.

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
The "This trail is 4900 miles long" banner is located on the south east corner of the visitor center. The other side 

The Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail commemorates the journey that Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, along with the rest of the expedition, took met traveled, camped, hunted, fished, and met with the native peoples in this area of middle Missouri. Visitors walking thorugh the garden will find interpretive panels on the expedition, the local wildlife, and native plants.
audioDescription: A large vinyl banner secured between two steel posts. This banner is two-sided and has different information and images on each side. If you are standing in front of the banner facing north, the banner is divided into six sections, dissected by a large dark green x. At the center of the x is a dark green rectangle with rounded corners. Inside the rectangle, in teal letters, the banner reads, you are here. Inside the top section of the x, the background is a light-green map. The National Park Service arrowhead logo is in the center of the map background. Moving clockwise from the logo, the next section is an image of a river at sunset. There is a small rainstorm in the background and the riverbanks are forested with evergreen trees. Below that, the next section is an image of one person in a canoe. The person is wearing a hat and backpack and is sitting below a small waterfall. The next section is the bottom of the x. It has a light green map as a background. The Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail logo is atop the background. It is a white, rounded triangle with two men at the center. One of the men is pointing. The outside of the triangle reads, Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. The next image is of a National Park Service ranger showing an item to some children who are sitting in the grass. Behind her, a brown banner reads, National Park Week. The final image is of a person standing on a wooden pier overlooking a bright blue body of water. Behind the person a stand of trees and a rock face are visible. At the bottom of the banner is a dark green section with white words. The section reads, Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center and Headquarters. Nps.gov/LECL National Park Service Regional Office Department of the Interior Regions 3, 4, & 5. Nps.gov/MWRO. If you are standing in front of the banner, but facing south, the top of the banner is dark green and has teal words inside the dark green. The words read, “this trail is 4,900 miles long.” Under the dark green is a teal horizontal stripe and some lighter green beneath that. There are stylized mountains and a sun added to a picture of two people on bicycles. They are cycling on a dirt trail with prairie grass on either side. There are deciduous trees in the distance. Beneath the cyclists there are white words that read, “Omaha is a point along the 4,900 mile Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail, a historic corridor that connects 16 states and over 65 tribes. Beneath the words are three horizontal blocks of color. The top is sage green, the next is teal, and the bottom is dark green. At the bottom of the sign are teal words that read, “Check out the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center to learn more.” Just above the words are two red arrows pointing toward the National Park Service building. Next to the words and arrows is the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail logo. It is a white triangle with rounded sides with a smaller off-white triangle with rounded sides inside. Around the outside edge are words that read, Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. Inside the off-white triangle are brown silhouettes of two frontiersmen. One is pointing with an arm outstretched.

title: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center - Bur Oak
listingDescription: "Bur Oak" interpretive plaque. Part of the audio tour for the Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center in Omaha, Nebraska.

images.credit: NPS Photo
images.altText: A small sign is placed near a green plant. The sign describes the Bur Oak.
images.title: Bur Oak LECL
images.caption: Bur Oak

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Bur Oak interpretive plaque.

The Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail commemorates the journey that Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, along with the rest of the expedition, took met traveled, camped, hunted, fished, and met with the native peoples in this area of middle Missouri. Visitors walking through the garden will find interpretive panels on the expedition, the local wildlife, and native plants.
audioDescription: A small sign is placed near a Bur Oak. The sign describes the Bur Oak. There is a black bar across the top of the sign. It has white letters that read Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. Beneath the black bar is a light blue rectangle that contains words and a drawing of a Bur Oak cluster. The words above the Bur Oak cluster are in two different fonts. The bold font reads Bur Oak, while italic font below the bold font reads Quercus macrocarpa. Beneath the italic words is an image of the Bur oak cluster. The cluster contains two small, brown acorns and two green oak leaves connected to a light brown twig. The leaves have pointed lobes and their surface appears shiny. There is one long vein running from the tip of the leaf to the stem. Veins also run from the center vein out to the tip of each lobe. The acorns are round and slightly elongated. Their outer shells are several different shades of light brown and light yellow. Each shell covers more than half of its acorn. The shells have a rough and hairy texture. The bottom of the acorn is visible below each shell. It is dark brown, and has a smooth texture. Below the Bur Oak cluster are italic words that read, … a small species of white oak which is loaded with acorns of an excellent flavor very little of the bitter roughness of the nuts of most species of oak… the cup which contains the acorn is fringed on it’s edges and imbraces the nut about one half. Beneath the italic words are words that are not italicized. They read -Meriwether Lewis, September 16, 1804. Beneath those words are more words, not italicized, that read, “Bur oak” refers to the coarse hairs that grown on the cupule or cup that holds the nut.

title: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center - Captain Lewis Will Give Us Accounts of New Things Only
listingDescription: "Captain Lewis Will Give Us Accounts of New Things Only" interpretive plaque. Part of the audio tour for the Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center in Omaha, Nebraska.

images.credit: NPS Photo
images.altText: A wayside mounted on a frame built of black, square metal tubing
images.title: Capt Lewis Will Give Accounts LECL
images.caption: Pres. Jefferson instructed Capt. Lewis to collect information on everything they saw.

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
"Captain Lewis will give us accounts of new things only" interpretive plaque.

The Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail commemorates the journey that Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, along with the rest of the expedition, took met traveled, camped, hunted, fished, and met with the native peoples in this area of middle Missouri. Visitors walking through the garden will find interpretive panels on the expedition, the local wildlife, and native plants.
audioDescription: A wayside mounted on a frame built of black, square metal tubing. At the top, the wayside has a black bar with white words. On the left the words read, Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. On the right the words read, National Park Service U.S. Department of Interior. Next to those words is a picture of the National Park Service logo. Beneath the bar, the background is light blue and fades into a map of the north-western United States. In the upper right corner Lakes Superior, Michigan and Huron are visible. Overtop of the light blue background, words are written in black. Large, italicized words say, Capt. Lewis… will… give us account of new things only. Beneath that in small, non-italicized words is written, Thomas Jefferson, February 28, 1803. Beneath that are more non-italicized words that read, Between 1804 and 1806, the Corps of Discovery traveled from St. Louis, Missouri, to the Pacific coast and back. President Jefferson instructed Meriwether Lewis to collect information on “the soil and face of the country, [its] growth and vegetable productions… the animals of the country generally, especially those not of the U.S.” In fulfilling these instructions, members of the Expedition were the first to describe for science 122 animals and 178 plants. The explorers’ written descriptions and the seeds and specimens they collected were Jefferson’s window into the new west. There is a large picture of a prairie dog. Its caption reads, Black-tailed prairie dog (Cynomys ludvicianus). The route of the trail is outlined across the map of the United States. There are pictures of species the Corps encountered along the trail. Near St. Louis Missouri is a picture of an Osage orange. Its caption reads, Osage orange (Maclura pomifera) “[S]o much do… [the Osage Indians] esteem the wood of this tree for… making their bows, that they travel many hundreds of miles in quest of it… The Indians give an extravagant account of the exquisite odour of this fruit when it has obtained maturity…” Meriwether Lewis letter to Thomas Jefferson, March 26, 1804. Above the Osage orange is an image of a black-billed magpie sitting on a branch. Its caption reads, Black-billed magpie (pica pica). Near Omaha, Nebraska is an image of a badger. It has a caption that reads, Badger (Taxidea taxus neglecta) “it is very clumsy and runs very slow. I have in two instances out run this animal and caught it. In this respect they are not much more fleet than the porcupine.” Meriwether Lewis, February 26, 1806. Near Yankton, South Dakota is an image of a pronghorn antelope. Its caption reads, (Antilocapra americana) “a curious annamil resembling a Goat… the legs like a Deer. Feet like a Goat. Horns like a Goat only forked… Such an anamil was never yet known in the U.S. States.” John Ordway, September 14, 1804. In central North Dakota is an image of a Grizzly bear. Its caption reads, Grizzly bear (Ursus arctos) “these bear being so hard to die rather intimidates us all…” Meriwether Lewis, May 11, 1805. Near Williston, North Dakota is an image of a Prickly Pear cactus. Its caption reads, Prickly pear cactus (Opuntia fragilis) “my feet is very much bruised and cut… and constantly Stuck full Prickley pear thorns, I pulled out 17 by the light of the fire…” William Clark July 19, 1805. In the south-central part of the Idaho panhandle is an image of a Western tanager. Its caption reads, Western tanager (Piranga ludoviciana) “we meet with a beautiful little bird… the plumage is remarkably delicate; that of the neck and head is of fine orange and red. Meriwether Lewis, June 6, 1806. Near Lewiston, Idaho is an image of a Camas. Its caption reads, Camas (Camassia quamash) “the quawmash is now in blume from the colour of its bloom at a short distance it resembles lacks of fine clear water…” Meriwether Lewis, June 12, 1806. Near Cathlamet, Washington is an image of a Harbor seal. Its caption reads reads, Harbor seal (Phoca vituline) “I have reason to believe… that there are several species of seal on this coast…when we first saw those animals… we conceived they were the Sea Otter. But the Indians here have undeceived us.” Meriwether Lewis, February 23, 1806. At the mouth of the Columbia River in Washington is an image of a Eulachon. Its caption reads Eulachon (Thaleichthys pacificus) “he presented us with some Anchovies [eulachon] which had been well cured in their manner. We [found] them excellent.” Meriwether Lewis, March 6, 1806. At the bottom is an image of a Sharp-tailed grouse. Its caption reads, sharp-tailed grouse (Tympanuchus phasianellus). There is a caption at the bottom that reads, In 1805, the keelboat returned to Washington D.C. carrying 4 magpies, a prairie dog, and a sharp-tailed grouse. Only the prairie dog and one magpie survived the journey. Believing that “everything that comes from Louisiana must be interesting to the public,” Jefferson sent these two living pieces of the west to be displayed in Philadelphia.

title: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center - Cattail
listingDescription: "Cattail" interpretive plaque. Part of the audio tour for the Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center in Omaha, Nebraska.

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Cattail.

The Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail commemorates the journey that Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, along with the rest of the expedition, took met traveled, camped, hunted, fished, and met with the native peoples in this area of middle Missouri. Visitors walking through the garden will find interpretive panels on the expedition, the local wildlife, and native plants.
audioDescription: A small sign is placed near a group of Cattail. The sign describes the Cattail. There is a black bar across the top of the sign. It has white letters that read Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. Beneath the black bar is a light blue rectangle that contains words and a drawing of a Cattail bunch. The words above the Cattail bunch are in two different fonts. The bold font reads Cattail, while italic font below the bold font reads Typha latifolia. Beneath the italic words is the image of the Cattail bunch. Three cattail stalks are surrounded by long, thin blade-like leaves. Atop each cattail stalk, is a long, slender cylinder-shaped bloom. The blooms have a fuzzy texture and rounded ends. Each has a sharp point protruding from the top, as if the stem has continued right up through the bloom. There are italicized words beneath the picture of the Cattail bunch. The words read, The Indians of this neighborhood eat the root of the Cattail or Cooper’s flag. It is pleasantly taisted and appears very nutritious… this substance would make an excellent starch; nothing can be of pruer white than it is. Under the italicized words are non-italicized words. They read, -Meriwether Lewis, March 1, 1806. Under these words are more non-italicized words that read, Coopers, or barrel makers, place the plant’s long leaves between barrel staves to make them watertight.

The Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail commemorates the journey that Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, along with the rest of the expedition, took met traveled, camped, hunted, fished, and met with the native peoples in this area of middle Missouri. Visitors walking through the garden will find interpretive panels on the expedition, the local wildlife, and native plants.
audioDescription: A wayside mounted on a frame built of black, square metal tubing. At the top, the wayside has a black bar with white words. On one side, the words read, Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. On the other side the words read, National Park Service U.S. Department of Interior. Next to those words is a picture of the National Park Service logo in black and white. The National Park Service logo is in the shape of an arrowhead. In the background is a lone peak, covered in snow. In the foreground are pine trees and the silhouette of a bison. Beneath the black bar is an illustration of an earth lodge village. There are six earth lodges which are dome shaped and grown over with grass. The doors are reinforced by several timbers and each has a smoke hole in the center of the roof. A pathway, dotted with grass, winds between the lodges. The sky above the lodges is blue and speckled with clouds. A brown and black bird flies overhead. Over top of the sky is text written in large, bold, italic font. It reads, endeavor to make yourself acquainted… with… the nations. Beneath that in small, non-italic text it reads, Thomas Jefferson’s instructions to Meriwether Lewis, June 20, 1803. Beneath that in larger, non-italic text it reads, In August 1804, members of the Expedition visited villages like this one, homes to the Otoe and Missouria who lived in what is today Omaha. Planning to invite these tribes to a council, or meeting, the explorers found the villages deserted. The tribes had left to hunt buffalo. Throughout their journey, the men of the Expedition held formal councils with tribes they met. Jefferson instructed the explorers to make themselves “acquainted … with… the nations,” to note the “articles of commerce [the Indians] may need or furnish.” And to prepare descriptions of “food, clothing, & domestic accommodations.” The explorers met with tribes for reason of trade, ethnography, and diplomacy. They also relied on American Indians for information, food, and clothing.

bodyText:
Goldenrod

The Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail commemorates the journey that Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, along with the rest of the expedition, took met traveled, camped, hunted, fished, and met with the native peoples in this area of middle Missouri. Visitors walking through the garden will find interpretive panels on the expedition, the local wildlife, and native plants.
audioDescription: A small sign is placed near a Goldenrod. The sign describes the Goldenrod. There is a black bar across the top of the sign. It has white letters that read Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. Beneath the black bar is a light blue rectangle that contains words and a drawing of a Goldenrod sprig. The words above the Goldenrod sprig are in two different fonts. The bold font reads Goldenrod, while italic font below the bold font reads Solidago missouriensis. Beneath the italic words is the image of the Goldenrod sprig. The goldenrod sprig has a singular, green stock surrounded by long, thin leaves at the bottom and middle. The top of the stalk is covered in plumes of bright yellow flowers, intermixed with more long, thin leaves. The plumes at the very top show wide open flowers, which make the plant appear fuzzy. There are non-italicized words beneath the picture of the Goldenrod sprig. The words read, The goldenrod served as a sign to the Omaha people while on their summer buffalo hunt. When the Goldenrod began to bloom, they knew that their corn was beginning to ripen at home.

bodyText:
Granite Bird. 

The Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail commemorates the journey that Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, along with the rest of the expedition, took met traveled, camped, hunted, fished, and met with the native peoples in this area of middle Missouri. Visitors walking through the garden will find interpretive panels on the expedition, the local wildlife, and native plants.
audioDescription: A statue of a bird carved from tan and black speckled granite sits atop pea gravel. Behind the bird are native grasses and wildflowers. The bird is about 3 feet long and two feet tall at the head. It has one wing folded over the other, which comes to a rounded point at its back. There are feather details carved on the wings. The bird has a black rock ring inlaid around its neck, and black rock inlaid for an eye. It also has a black rock beak, into which ridges have been carved to illustrate where the beak opens. No legs or feet are visible, as the bid rests on the ground.

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Meadow Anemone interpretive plaque.

The Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail commemorates the journey that Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, along with the rest of the expedition, took met traveled, camped, hunted, fished, and met with the native peoples in this area of middle Missouri. Visitors walking through the garden will find interpretive panels on the expedition, the local wildlife, and native plants.
audioDescription: A small sign is placed near a meadow anemone. The sign describes the meadow anemone. There is a black bar across the top of the sign. It has white letters that read Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. Beneath the black bar is a light blue rectangle that contains words and a drawing of a meadow anemone. The words above the meadow anemone are in two different fonts. The bold font reads Meadow Anemone, while italic font below the bold font reads Anemone canadensis. Beneath the italic words is an image of a meadow anemone cluster. The cluster has one main, light yellow, stem and one smaller green stem. Dark green leaves protrude from each stem. The leaves are deeply cut and have a jagged appearance. From the center of the main stem a five-petaled flower blooms. The petals are white and rounded softly. In the center of the flower a clump of bright yellow stamens emerge. Below the meadow anemone cluster are non-italic words that read, The Meadow anemone is considered an esteemed medicine by American Indians. It serves as a general panacea. Herbivores avoid eating this plant because blistering agents in the foliage can irritate their gastrointestinal tracts.

title: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center - Miles to Destination Sign
listingDescription: "Miles to Destination" interpretive plaque. Part of the audio tour for the Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center in Omaha, Nebraska.

images.credit: NPS Photo
images.altText: A banner showing mile posts to four major cities from this spot
images.title: Miles to Destinations LECL
images.caption: One of the interpretive signs you'll see in the interpretive garden

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText: The Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail commemorates the journey that Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, along with the rest of the expedition, took met traveled, camped, hunted, fished, and met with the native peoples in this area of middle Missouri. Visitors walking through the garden will find interpretive panels on the expedition, the local wildlife, and native plants.
audioDescription: A large vinyl banner secured between two steel posts. This banner is two-sided and has different information and images on each side. If you are standing in front of the banner facing south, the banner is divided into six sections, dissected by a large dark green x. At the center of the x is a dark green rectangle with rounded corners. Inside the rectangle, in teal letters, the banner reads, you are here. Inside the top section of the x, the background is a light-green map. The National Park Service arrowhead logo is in the center of the map background. Moving clockwise from the logo, the next section is an image of a river at sunset. There is a small rainstorm in the background and the riverbanks are forested with evergreen trees. Below that, the next section is an image of one person in a canoe. The person is wearing a hat and backpack and is sitting below a small waterfall. The next section is the bottom of the x. It has a light green map as a background. The Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail logo is atop the background. It is a white, rounded triangle with two men at the center. One of the men is pointing. The outside of the triangle reads, Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. The next image is of a National Park Service ranger showing an item to some children who are sitting in the grass. Behind her, a brown banner reads, National Park Week. The final image is of a person standing on a wooden pier overlooking a bright blue body of water. Behind the person a stand of trees and a rock face are visible. At the bottom of the banner is a dark green section with white words. The section reads, Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center and Headquarters. Nps.gov/LECL National Park Service Regional Office Department of the Interior Regions 3, 4, & 5. Nps.gov/MWRO. If you are standing in front of the banner facing north, the background of the banner has a map of part of the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail, the words River La Platte are visible on the map. The map fades into blue sky towards the top of the banner. In the foreground of the banner, there is a green sign post with four arrow signs attached. Each sign is two-tone sage green and has dark green words. The top sign points West and says Pacific Ocean 3,200 miles. The sign beneath that points East and says Pittsburgh Pennsylvania 1,700 miles. The sign beneath that points East and says St. Louis Missouri 530 miles. The sign beneath that points West and says Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center. It also has the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail logo on it. The logo is a white triangle with rounded sides with a smaller off-white triangle with rounded sides inside. Around the outer edge are words that read, Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. Inside the off-white triangle are brown silhouettes of two frontiersmen. One is pointing with an arm outstretched. At the bottom of the sign post is a sage green and teal compass rose on a white and cream background. There is a black circle around the outside of the compass rose with green words on it. They read, connecting 16 states and over 65 tribes commemorate and protect 4,900 miles.

title: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center - Missouri Evening Primrose

images.altText: A small sign is placed near a green plant. The sign describes the Missouri Evening Primrose
images.title: Missouri Evening Primrose LECL
images.caption: Missouri Evening Primrose

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Missour Evening Primrose.

The Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail commemorates the journey that Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, along with the rest of the expedition, took met traveled, camped, hunted, fished, and met with the native peoples in this area of middle Missouri. Visitors walking through the garden will find interpretive panels on the expedition, the local wildlife, and native plants.
audioDescription: A small sign is placed near a Missouri Evening Primrose. The sign describes the Missouri Evening Primrose. There is a black bar across the top of the sign. It has white letters that read Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. Beneath the black bar is a light blue rectangle that contains words and a drawing of a Missouri evening primrose cluster. The words above the Missouri evening primrose cluster are in two different fonts. The bold font reads Missouri Evening Primrose, while italic font below the bold font reads Oenothera macrocarpa. Beneath the italic words is the image of the Missouri evening primrose cluster. Three bright yellow, four-petaled flowers rise up from a clump of narrow, pointed dark green leaves. At the center of each flower are many lighter yellow stamens. The stalks upon which the flowers sit are light brown and yellow. Each leaf has a center vein running tip-to-tip. There are non-italicized words beneath the picture of the Missouri evening primrose cluster. The words read, Also known as Ozark Sundrops, these flowers open at dusk and last only one evening. Though they do not need a pollinator to reproduce, the primrose is often visited by night-flying Sphinx Moths that are one of several nocturnal species drawn to the light-colored flowers reflected in the moonlight. Look for the 3-4 inch papery capsules that gave rise to the primrose’s species name, macrocarpa.

images.altText: A large flat tan and gray rock with jagged edges. Words and channels have been carved into the rock.
images.title: Missouri River Then and Now LECL
images.caption: Missouri River Then and Now

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Missouri River Then and Now

The Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail commemorates the journey that Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, along with the rest of the expedition, took met traveled, camped, hunted, fished, and met with the native peoples in this area of middle Missouri. Visitors walking through the garden will find interpretive panels on the expedition, the local wildlife, and native plants.
audioDescription: A large flat tan and gray rock with jagged edges, whose shape resembles a parallelogram. At the lower left and right corners the top layer of rock has been chipped away, leaving the under layer exposed. Words and channels have been carved into the rock. The top, in large font, reads, then. Below that text, in smaller font, words read, warm, wide, slow. Beneath that, a winding channel has been carved. Islands have been left in the channel with smaller streams running between them. The channel terminates in a hole that has been carved through the rock. Beneath that channel another channel has been carved. It snakes slightly, but is much straighter than the one above it. There are no islands left in this channel. It also terminates into the hole carved through the rock. Beneath this channel words read, straight, deep, narrow. Beneath that text, a larger font reads, now.

images.title: Narrow-leaf coneflower
images.caption: Narrow-leaf coneflower

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Narrow-leaf Coneflower interpretive plaque.

The Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail commemorates the journey that Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, along with the rest of the expedition, took met traveled, camped, hunted, fished, and met with the native peoples in this area of middle Missouri. Visitors walking through the garden will find interpretive panels on the expedition, the local wildlife, and native plants.
audioDescription: A small sign is placed near a narrow-leaf coneflower. The sign describes the narrow-leaf coneflower. There is a black bar across the top of the sign. It has white letters that read Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. Beneath the black bar is a light blue rectangle that contains words and a drawing of two stems of narrow-leaf coneflower. The words above the two stems of narrow-leaf coneflower are in two different fonts. The bold font reads Narrow-leaf Coneflower, while italic font below the bold font reads Echinacea angustifolia. Beneath the italic words is the image of two stalks of narrow-leaf coneflower. Two long, thick, green stems emerge from clumps of long slender leaves. The stems are covered in short, stiff, hair-like structures. Each stem has one coneflower bloom at the top. The center of the blooms are orange, spiny and cone-shaped. Long, thin and light pink petals surround the cone and droop away from the center. There are italicized words beneath the picture of the narrow-leaf coneflower. The words read, I also collected a Plant the root of which is a Cure for the Bite of a mad dog & Snake… Beneath the italicized words are non-italicized words that read, -William Clark, March 21, 1805. Beneath these words are more non-italicized words that read, This plant was, and still is, a widely used medicinal plant of the Plains Indians. It was used as painkiller and for a variety of ailments, including toothache, coughs, colds, sore throats, and snake bites.
