images.altText: A wayside mounted on a frame built of black, square metal tubing
images.title: Nature Exerted Herself LECL
images.caption: Nature Exerted Herself to Beautify the Scenery

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Nature Exerted Herself to Beautify the Scenery

The Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail commemorates the journey that Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, along with the rest of the expedition, took met traveled, camped, hunted, fished, and met with the native peoples in this area of middle Missouri. Visitors walking through the garden will find interpretive panels on the expedition, the local wildlife, and native plants.
audioDescription: A wayside mounted on a frame built of black, square metal tubing. At the top, the wayside has a black bar with white words. On one side, the words read, Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. On the other side the words read, National Park Service U.S. Department of Interior. Next to those words is a picture of the National Park Service logo in black and white. The National Park Service logo is in the shape of an arrowhead. In the background is a lone peak, covered in snow. In the foreground are pine trees and the silhouette of a bison. Beneath the black bar is an illustration of prairie grassland under a partially cloudy sky. In the distance, the grassland is a homogenous golden color, but in the foreground a variety of grasses and flowers are visible. A small brown and yellow bird sits on a small, leafless twig. Beneath it, an orange and black butterfly sits on a cluster of red blooms. At the top of the illustration words are written. Large, italicized font at the top reads, Nature exerted herself to butify the Senery. Beneath that in smaller, non-italicized font is written, William Clark, July 4, 1804. Beneath that in two, non-italicized columns is written, The tallgrass prairies of Nebraska stook in stark contrast to the forested homelands of the explorers. Dense grasses, some taller than a man, covered the land. Lewis and Clark noted beauty in the vast reaches of waist-high grasses, a beauty beyond picturesque scenery. Lush grasses suggested fertile soils and the promise of bountiful farmlands for a growing country. Today, these promises fulfilled, less than one percent of the original tallgrass prairie remains to inspire us as it did Lewis and Clark.

title: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center - People, Places, and Stories
listingDescription: "People, Places, and Stories" interpretive plaque. Part of the audio tour for the Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center in Omaha, Nebraska.

images.credit: NPS Photo
images.altText: A wayside mounted on a frame built of black, square metal tubing.
images.title: People, Places, Stories LECL
images.caption: People, Places, and Stories interpetive panel

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
People, Places, and Stories

The Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail commemorates the journey that Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, along with the rest of the expedition, took met traveled, camped, hunted, fished, and met with the native peoples in this area of middle Missouri. Visitors walking through the garden will find interpretive panels on the expedition, the local wildlife, and native plants.
audioDescription: A wayside mounted on a frame built of black, square metal tubing. At the top, the wayside has a black bar with white words. On one side, the words read, Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. On the other side the words read, National Park Service U.S. Department of Interior. Next to those words is a picture of the National Park Service logo in black and white. The National Park Service logo is in the shape of an arrowhead. In the background is a lone peak, covered in snow. In the foreground are pine trees and the silhouette of a bison. Beneath the black bar there is an image of a sepia-toned map. On top of the map is some text in two columns. Beneath that text are three photos, which are in a horizontal line across the map. Each photo has a caption. The title text at the top reads, People, Places, Stories in large, bold print. Beneath that in smaller print it reads, The joint efforts of many individuals and groups – among them the military men and scientists, a president and an enslaved man, French-speaking boatmen and American Indians, women and men – determined the fate of the Corps of Discovery. Today more than 100 groups work with the National Park Service to share the stories of the Expedition and to preserve the resources of the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trial. Partners include a diverse group of federal agencies, tribal nations, state and local entities, and even private land owners. Many voices tell the stories of the Trail. To hear them all is to hear the true story. Beneath this text are the three images. The first is an image of a wooden fort, viewed through an open gate, with a rustic table and stool visible in the courtyard. The pickets of the fence are made from individual branches that have been sharpened to a point at the top. There are trees in the fore- and background. The caption for this photo reads, Fort Clatsop, Oregon. The next photo is of a seated National Park Service uniform ranger in uniform and standing child in indigenous regalia. They are in front of a white tepee, and a grassy area with trees can be seen in the background. In front of the ranger and child are a wide variety of tools an instruments laid out on top of an animal skin. The caption for this photo reads, Park ranger and American Indian dancer. The third photo is of a footpath through some low brush. There are several ranges of mountains in the background, stands of evergreen trees in the middle ground, and red and green brush in the foreground. The caption for this photo reads, Trail to Sherman Peak, Washington. Beneath these photos is a wide brown bar with an image of a leather-bound journal on the left and some text in three columns on the right. In larger, bold font the text says, The Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. Beneath that in smaller text is written, The Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail stretches across 11 states: Illinois, Missouri, Kansas, Nebraska, Iowa, South Dakota, North Dakota, Montana, Idaho, Washington, and Oregon. The lands of more than 40 tribal nations – from the Iowa Tribe of Kansas and Nebraska to the Clatsop/Nehalem Confederated Tribes in Oregon – are on or near today’s Trail. Seeing the vistas beheld by Lewis and hearing the same rushing rivers Clark heard connect us to our history. The National Park Service and its partners work to protect the remnants of what the Corps described.

title: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center - Prairie Blazing Star
listingDescription: "Prairie Blazing Star" interpretive plaque. Part of the audio tour for the Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center in Omaha, Nebraska.

images.credit: NPS Photo
images.altText: A small sign is placed near a green plant. The sign describes the Prairie Blazing Star.
images.title: Prairie Blazing Star LECL
images.caption: Prairie Blazing Star

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Prairie Blazing Star interpretive plaque.

The Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail commemorates the journey that Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, along with the rest of the expedition, took met traveled, camped, hunted, fished, and met with the native peoples in this area of middle Missouri. Visitors walking through the garden will find interpretive panels on the expedition, the local wildlife, and native plants.
audioDescription: A small sign is placed near a Prairie Blazing Star. The sign describes the Prairie Blazing Star. There is a black bar across the top of the sign. It has white letters that read Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. Beneath the black bar is a light blue rectangle that contains words and a drawing of two sprigs of Prairie Blazing Star. The words above the Prairie Blazing Star sprigs are in two different fonts. The bold font reads Prairie Blazing Star, while italic font below the bold font reads Liatris pycnostachya. Beneath the italic words is the image of the two Prairie Blazing Star sprigs. Two spikes of rosey-purple cylindrical, stalkless flower heads densely crowd up a very leafy stem. Stamens and styles protrude from the purple, tufted flower heads at the top of the flower head bunches, creating a fuzzy appearance. The stems are covered with small, green, grass-like leaves. There are non-italicized words beneath the picture of the Prairie Blazing Star sprigs. The words read, Omahas applied powered gayfeather root as a poultice for external inflammation. Tea made from the plant was also used to treat abdominal infirmaries. Translated, the Omaha and Ponca names mean “medicine.”

title: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center - Preserving Our Heritage
listingDescription: "Preserving Our Heritage" interpretive plaque. Part of the audio tour for the Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center in Omaha, Nebraska.

images.credit: NPS Photo
images.altText: A wayside mounted on a frame built of black, square metal tubing.
images.title: Preserving Our Heritage LECL
images.caption: Preserving Our Heritage interpretive panel

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Preserving Our Heritage

The Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail commemorates the journey that Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, along with the rest of the expedition, took met traveled, camped, hunted, fished, and met with the native peoples in this area of middle Missouri. Visitors walking through the garden will find interpretive panels on the expedition, the local wildlife, and native plants.
audioDescription: A wayside mounted on a frame built of black, square metal tubing. At the top, the wayside has a black bar with white words. On one side, the words read, Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. On the other side the words read, National Park Service U.S. Department of Interior. Next to those words is a picture of the National Park Service logo in black and white. The National Park Service logo is in the shape of an arrowhead. In the background is a lone peak, covered in snow. In the foreground are pine trees and the silhouette of a bison. Beneath the black bar there is an image of a sepia-toned map. On top of the map is some text in one column. Beneath that text are three photos, which are in a horizontal line across the map. Each photo has a caption. The title text at the top reads, Preserving Our Heritage in large, bold print. Beneath that in smaller print it reads, The Midwest Regional Office, located in Omaha since 1937, assists NPS sites across the heartland of the United States. Inside this building, more than 200 people – from architects to wildland fire managers – work to sustain the heritage of all Americans: our national park system. Beneath this text are the three images. The first is an image of a round granite building, whose roof is supported by large columns. Atop the column-supported roof is a saucer dome. There is a large, tree-lined pathway leading to the structure. The trees are covered in pink blooms. The caption for this photo reads, George Rogers Clark National Historic Park, Indiana. The next photo is of an expanse of prairie covered in yellow and purple wildflowers. There are low pushes dotted throughout the prairies and dense trees can be seen in the background. The caption for this photo reads, Homestead National Monument of America, Nebraska. The third photo is of a shoreline, whose dark brown surf-zone has been washed clean. Above the surf-zone low, tangles of plants can be seen. In the distance, light colored cliffs, topped with trees, meet the water. The water is rough with white-capping waves. The caption for this photo reads, Pictured Rocks National Lake Shore, Michigan. Beneath these photos is a wide brown bar with an image of a light tan ranger hat with a dark brown hat band on the left and some text in three columns on the right. In larger, bold font the text says, About the Midwest Region. Beneath that in smaller text is written, The Midwest Region of the National Park Service includes 13 states: North Dakota, Nebraska, Iowa, Kansas, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, Michigan, Wisconsin, and Minnesota. There are more than 50 National Park Service sites in the Midwest Region. These include parks, monuments, battlefields, historic sites, trails, lakeshores, and heritage areas. The third column of text begins with large bold font which reads, Mission of the National Park Service. Beneath that, in smaller italic font, reads, To conserve the scenery and the natural and historic objects and the wild life therein and to provide for the enjoyment of the same in such a manner and by such means as will leave them unimpaired for the enjoyment of future generations. Beneath this text, in smaller, non-italic text it reads, From 1916 Organic Act establishing the National Park Service.

images.caption: Red Columbine

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
The Red Columbine interpretive panel.

The Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail commemorates the journey that Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, along with the rest of the expedition, took met traveled, camped, hunted, fished, and met with the native peoples in this area of middle Missouri. Visitors walking through the garden will find interpretive panels on the expedition, the local wildlife, and native plants.
audioDescription: A small sign is placed near a Red Columbine. The sign describes the Red Columbine. There is a black bar across the top of the sign. It has white letters that read Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. Beneath the black bar is a light blue rectangle that contains words and a drawing of a Red Columbine bunch. The words above the Red Columbine bunch are in two different fonts. The bold font reads Red Columbine, while italic font below the bold font reads Aquilegia canadensis. Beneath the italic words is an image of the Red Columbine bunch. One small light-green stem becomes many red stems. There are small leaf-clusters at the bases of these stems. Atop each red stem is one Red Columbine flower. In the center of each flower is a cluster of bright yellow stamens, which are surrounded by pale yellow petals which become red near their base. On the exterior of the flower, bright red petals spur upward into points. There are italicized words beneath the picture of the Red Columbine. The words read, the seed of a plant given to me by the recara (Arikara) chief who accompanied us to the mandanes (Mandans) he informed me that a tea of the seed was a strong diarettic. Beneath the italic words are words that are not italicized. They read -Meriwether Lewis, November 17, 1804. Beneath those words are more words, not italicized, that read, The genus name Aquilegia is Latin for eagle and refers to the spurred petals that resemble an eagle’s talons.

River Critters Exhibit

audioDescription: A rock slab, about 2 feet wide by 4 feet tall, that is generally rectangular, but has ragged edges. In front and behind the rock slab are other, smaller slabs that stabilize the larger slab. The slabs are tan with lighter cream-colored and black variations running throughout. The slab and supports are surrounded by tall grasses. Words and images have been carved into the larger slab and are colored black. At the top left the largest font reads, River Critters. Next to that text is an image of a bird with wings upwardly outstretched. The bird has a ring around its neck, forked tail feathers, and a short, pointed beak. Beneath the large text and image of the bird is smaller text that reads, Environmental Play Area. Beneath that in still smaller text reads, funding for this play area was donated in appreciation of the civic contributions of George Krauss and his lifetime of service to the Omaha community. Beneath that text is a line with four egg-shapes in a cluster in the middle of the line. Beneath that line text reads, The America First Foundation John and Carmen Gottschalk Mike and Gail Yanney and friends at the Burlington Capital Group.

images.caption: Spiderwort

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Spiderwort interpretive plaque.

The Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail commemorates the journey that Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, along with the rest of the expedition, took met traveled, camped, hunted, fished, and met with the native peoples in this area of middle Missouri. Visitors walking through the garden will find interpretive panels on the expedition, the local wildlife, and native plants.
audioDescription: A small sign is placed near a Spiderwort. The sign describes the Spiderwort. There is a black bar across the top of the sign. It has white letters that read Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. Beneath the black bar is a light blue rectangle that contains words and a drawing of a Spiderwort cluster. The words above the spiderwort cluster are in two different fonts. The bold font reads Spiderwort, while italic font below the bold font reads Tradescantia occidentalis. Beneath the italic words is the image of the Spiderwort cluster. There is a thick clump of long, slender dark green leaves. From this clump, thin stalks emerge, each topped with a purple, three-petaled flower. Each flower has bright yellow stamens at the center. There are non-italicized words beneath the picture of the Spiderwort cluster. The words read, The Dakota use this plant as a love song charm. Walking alone on the prairie a young man might sing this song to the spiderwort, representative of the girl he loved. Beneath the non-italicized words are some italicized words. The italicized words read, we little dewey flower so blessed and so shy, Thou’rt dear to me, and for My love for thee I’d die. Beneath these italicized words are more non-italicized words that read, “Spider” comes from a web-like slime that is drawn into thin threads when the stem is broken and pulled apart.

title: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center - Sturgeon Statue and Bench
listingDescription: Sturgeon statue and bench. Part of the audio tour for the Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center in Omaha, Nebraska.

images.credit: NPS Photo
images.altText: A statue of a sturgeon made of speckled tan granite lays atop a paved patio space
images.title: Sturgeon Statue and Bench LECL
images.caption: The Sturgeon Statue and Bench

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Sturgeon statue and bench.

The Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail commemorates the journey that Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, along with the rest of the expedition, took met traveled, camped, hunted, fished, and met with the native peoples in this area of middle Missouri. Visitors walking through the garden will find interpretive panels on the expedition, the local wildlife, and native plants.
audioDescription: A stylized statue of a sturgeon carved from tan-colored and black speckled granite lays atop a paved patio space. Around the back of the sturgeon, in a semi-circle about three feet from the sturgeon’s tail, is a stone bench with words carved into it. There are bushes planted behind the bench. The sturgeon is about five feet long and about two feet high at its dorsal fin, though it is laying slight curved at the middle. The sturgeon has a shovel-shaped head and long snout that comes to a rounded point at the end. The sturgeon’s pectoral fins curve toward its tail, as does its dorsal fin. It has a long, forked tail that is longer at the top than at the bottom. The sturgeon has black-colored rock inlaid for eyes. Directly behind the sturgeon, the words on the bench read, Sister river is the life blood of mother earth she holds the code of our ancestors and the prophesy of our future life. Love her. To the right of the center section, another section of the bench reads, Carolyn K. Fiscus Ho-chunk Nation of Nebraska. To the left of the center section is a button inset into the stone. It is surrounded by a 2 inch by 2 inch metal plate. Before the button is pushed it is illuminated red. Once pushed, the button turns to green. The word push is etched into the rock above the metal plate.

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Sweetgrass interpretive plaque.

The Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail commemorates the journey that Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, along with the rest of the expedition, took met traveled, camped, hunted, fished, and met with the native peoples in this area of middle Missouri. Visitors walking through the garden will find interpretive panels on the expedition, the local wildlife, and native plants.
audioDescription: A small sign is placed near some sweetgrass. The sign describes the sweetgrass. There is a black bar across the top of the sign. It has white letters that read Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. Beneath the black bar is a light blue rectangle that contains words and a drawing of a sweetgrass bunch. The words above the sweetgrass bunch are in two different fonts. The bold font reads sweetgrass, while italic font below the bold font reads Hierochloe odorata. Beneath the italic words is an image of a sweetgrass bunch. The bunch contains many long, thin blades of grass that are pointed on the ends. The blades are dark green and some round over in the middle, some the tips of the blades point down. Some of the tips point up. In the center of the bunch is a cluster of flowers on top of a light green, tall, spindly stalk. The flowers are bell-shaped and are white and light yellow. Below the Sweetgrass cluster are italic words that read, the sweet sented grass which grows very abundant on this river is either twisted or plaited and woarn around the neck... Beneath the italic words are words that are not italicized. They read -Meriwether Lewis, August 21, 1805. Beneath those words are more words, not italicized, that read, Sweetgrass is used by many American Indians in prayer; for smudging or purifying ceremonies and consider it a sacred plant. It is usually braided, dried, and burned to release its sweet vanilla-like fragrance.

title: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center - The Council Was Held
listingDescription: "The Council Was Held" interpretive plaque. Part of the audio tour for the Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center in Omaha, Nebraska.

images.credit: NPS Photo
images.altText: A wayside mounted on a frame built of black, square metal tubing.
images.title: The Council was held LECL
images.caption: The Council Was Held interpretive plaque

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
The Council Was Held interpretive plaque.

The Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail commemorates the journey that Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, along with the rest of the expedition, took met traveled, camped, hunted, fished, and met with the native peoples in this area of middle Missouri. Visitors walking through the garden will find interpretive panels on the expedition, the local wildlife, and native plants.
audioDescription: A wayside mounted on a frame built of black, square metal tubing. At the top, the wayside has a black bar with white words. On one side, the words read, Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. On the other side the words read, National Park Service U.S. Department of Interior. Next to those words is a picture of the National Park Service logo in black and white. The National Park Service logo is in the shape of an arrowhead. In the background is a lone peak, covered in snow. In the foreground are pine trees and the silhouette of a bison. Beneath the black bar is an illustration of a group of men along a riverbank. Under a shade structure of white cloth strung between four wooden poles, a group of men in military uniform council with a group of indigenous men. Laying on the ground between the indigenous men are a pile of blankets and containers. One holds something in his hands. Several of the military men hold rifles, while one holds a book and quill pen. At the feet of one of the military men, a black dog lays on the ground. The American flag is on a wooden pole in the background, and a wooden keel boat can be seen at the river’s edge. Across the top of the illustration words are written. In large italicized words is written, the Council was held. Beneath that in non-italicized letters is written, Sergeant Charles Floyd, August 3, 1804. Beneath that are larger, non-italicized words is written in two columns, Near Here the Corps of Discovery held its first council, making speeches and presenting gifts to the Otoe and Missouria. Communicating through an interpreter, members of the Expedition believed their message was clear. But were they? This meeting was the first of many formal and informal exchanges between members of the Expedition and tribes along the trail. The Expedition crossed the territories of more than 100 American Indian tribes. Oral tradition, passed from generation to generation within tribes, preserves the stories of the Expedition.

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Western Serviceberry 

The Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail commemorates the journey that Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, along with the rest of the expedition, took met traveled, camped, hunted, fished, and met with the native peoples in this area of middle Missouri. Visitors walking through the garden will find interpretive panels on the expedition, the local wildlife, and native plants.
audioDescription: A small sign is placed near a Western Serviceberry. The sign describes the Western Serviceberry. There is a black bar across the top of the sign. It has white letters that read Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. Beneath the black bar is a light blue rectangle that contains words and a drawing of a Western Serviceberry bunch. The words above the Western serviceberry bunch are in two different fonts. The bold font reads Western Serviceberry, while italic font below the bold font reads Amelanchier alnifolia. Beneath the italic words is the image of the Western Serviceberry bunch. Seven oval-shaped and toothed leaves grow, each on their own stem. The leaves are shades of dark and light green and have one large center vein and smaller veins starting from the center and moving outward. There are eight serviceberries, each on their own stem, which are varying shades of dark red, light green and pink. Each berry has a star shape on the blossom end of the fruit. There are italicized words beneath the picture of the Western Serviceberry bunch. The words read, …the fruit is the same form but for the most part larger more luscious and of so deep a perple that on first sight you would think them black. Under the italicized words are non-italicized words that read, -Meriwether Lewis, July 17, 1805. Beneath those italicized words are more italicized words that read, Serviceberry was often used for pemmican: a mixture of animal fat, dried meat, and crushed berries. Serviceberries are also popular in the production of jams and jellies.

title: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center - Westwardly by the Waters
listingDescription: "Westwardly by the Waters" interpretive plaque. Part of the audio tour for the Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center in Omaha, Nebraska.

images.credit: NPS Photo
images.altText: A wayside mounted on a frame built of black, square metal tubing.
images.title: Westwardly by the Waters
images.caption: Westwardly by the Waters interpretive panel

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Interpetive Panel: Westwardly by the Waters

The Interpretive Garden at the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail commemorates the journey that Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, along with the rest of the expedition, took met traveled, camped, hunted, fished, and met with the native peoples in this area of middle Missouri. Visitors walking through the garden will find interpretive panels on the expedition, the local wildlife, and native plants.
audioDescription: A wayside mounted on a frame built of black, square metal tubing. At the top, the wayside has a black bar with white words. On one side, the words read, Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. On the other side the words read, National Park Service, U.S. Department of Interior. Next to those words is a picture of the National Park Service logo in black and white. The National Park Service logo is the shape of an arrowhead. In the background is a lone peak, covered in snow. In the foreground are pine trees and the silhouette of a bison. Beneath the black bar is an image of a river painting as a background for text. In the image, the river snakes through prairie grassland. The prairie is dotted with varying kinds of low bushes and grasses. There are some islands that emerge from the river water and have grass growing atop, as well. There is a downed tree rising from the water. In the distance are bluffs with vegetation growing atop them and trees in front. Above the bluffs is a pale blue sky with wispy clouds. Over the sky words are written in black. Large, italic words at the top read, Westwardly by the Waters. Beneath that in small, italic font is written, Albert Gallatin letter to Thomas Jefferson, April 13, 1803. Beneath that are two columns of small, non-italic words. They say, In 1803 the Missouri River carried the hopes of the youth United States in its dark and unpredictable waters. President Thomas Jefferson sought a “direct and practicable water communication across this continent, for the purpose of commerce.” The Missouri River would be a corridor to increased American trade and wealth. Traveling west against the current, the Expedition entered the lands of the recently acquired Louisiana Purchase. Along this watery path, the explorers would meet the people who had called this land home for many generations. With each mile of the Expedition traveled on the Missouri River, the United States pushed westward. In the lower right-hand corner of the image are italicized, white words that read, The Indians of this neighborhood inform us, that the Missouri is navigable nearly to its source, and … at a distance not exceeding half a [day’s] march, there is a large river… We believe this stream to be the…Columbia river…we shall probably find but little difficulty in passing to the Ocean. Beneath those words are smaller, non-italicized words also written in white. They say, Meriwether Lewis letter to his mother, March 31, 1805.

title: Lewis and Clark National Wildlife Refuge
listingDescription: Near the mouth of the Columbia River, the Lewis and Clark National Wildlife Refuge is a quiet, undisturbed natural area that appears much the same as when the Corps of Discovery traveled along the river in the fall of 1805 and spring of 1806.

images.credit: USFWS
images.altText: A detailed map of the Lewis and Clark National Wildlife Refuge showing the many islands, sandbars an
images.title: Lewis and Clark NWR Map
images.caption: Map of Lewis and Clark NWR Map

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Near the mouth of the Columbia River, the Lewis and Clark National Wildlife Refuge is a quiet, undisturbed natural area that appears much the same as when the Corps of Discovery traveled along the river in the fall of 1805 and spring of 1806. 

Managed by the U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service, the refuge encompasses 35,000 acres of mostly tidelands and open water, and 8,313 acres of islands and sand bars.  The calm waters of the refuge make it an ideal playground for kayakers as they move from island to island, avoiding the strong current of the Columbia, while coming face-to-face with nature of all types. 

The sanctuary is the winter home and resting area for a variety of migrating birds – including tundra swans, geese, and ducks.  Bald eagles are present year-round in 30 to 35 active nest sites. 
Estuarine waters provide vital food resources for juvenile salmon as they pause to become acclimated to salt water before entering the Pacific Ocean.  

Other fish species using the estuary include American shad, smelt, perch, starry flounder, bass, catfish, and Pacific lamprey.  Harbor seals use sandbars and mud flats as resting sites at low tides, while seals and California sea lions fish in the estuary.  Beaver, raccoon, weasel, mink, muskrat, river otter, white-tailed deer also live on the islands. 

The Lewis and Clark NWR was established in 1972 to preserve the vital fish and wildlife habitat along approximately 27 miles of the Columbia. 

Photo: U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service

Alt Text:  A detailed map of the Lewis and Clark National Wildlife Refuge showing the many islands, sandbars and waterways of the protected area of the Columbia River estuary.
audioDescription: Managed by the U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service, the refuge encompasses islands and sand bars.  The calm waters of the refuge make it an ideal playground for kayakers as they move from island to island, avoiding the strong current of the Columbia, while coming face-to-face with nature of all types.

title: Lewis and Clark State Park (Iowa)
listingDescription: In August 1804, the Corps of Discovery moved up the Missouri River along what is today western Iowa and eastern Nebraska. The party camped on August 9 in a broad, wooded area where the river made a tight bend. The Loess Hills could be spotted to the east whenever there were gaps in the trees. This area is now Lewis and Clark State Park in Iowa.

images.credit: Iowa State Parks
images.altText: visitor center building with interpretive signs in the foreground
images.title: Lewis and Clark State Park (Iowa)
images.caption: Visitor center

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
In August 1804, the Corps of Discovery moved up the Missouri River along what is today western Iowa and eastern Nebraska.  The party camped on August 9 in a broad, wooded area where the river made a tight bend.  The Loess Hills could be spotted to the east whenever there were gaps in the trees. 

Between the 1830s and 1870s, the Missouri flooded many times and the main channel of the river migrated about two miles west, leaving behind a small oxbow lake.  Here is where local settlers of nearby Onawa, Iowa would create Blue Lake Park.  It became a part of the Iowa park system in 1924 when it was renamed Lewis and Clark State Park.

Today, you’ll still find the semi-circular blue lake, surrounded by sand dunes and groves of huge cottonwood trees.  And you’ll enjoy an impressive visitor center built in 2013 that houses a display on the Expedition, along with full-size replicas of the keelboat, two pirogues, the iron boat, a dugout canoe, and a bull boat. From April 15 to October 1, another replica keelboat provides guests with short tours of the lake.  

The 1930s-era Works Progress Administration (WPA) historic lodge still stands overlooking the water.  The park has more than 30 acres of picnic grounds with tables, fire grills, and drinking water.  And campers enjoy the large campground with electric and full hook-up sites, a modern restroom, and showers.  Those who seek water activities will enjoy a fine beach for sunbathing and swimming, and a boat ramp provides access to the lake.

The park’s Lewis and Clark Festival is held in June each year, featuring movies, history enactors in frontier attire, bluegrass music and historic presentations.  

The park is less than five miles from Onawa, Iowa on State Highway 175.  It is about 40 miles south of Sioux City.  To learn more, go to: https://www.iowadnr.gov/Places-to-Go/State-Parks/Iowa-State-Parks/parkdetails/parkid/610142
audioDescription: The Lewis and Clark State Park features a visitor center surrounded by trees. This building is constructed of stones and wood with large windows. Inside the center, you can find replicas of the keelboat, the iron boat, two pirogues, a bull boat, and a dugout canoe. Also in the state park, you will find a semi-circle blue lake with beaches, surrounded by sand dunes and forested areas of cottonwood trees.

quickFacts.value: The park is less than five miles from Onawa, Iowa on State Highway 175.  It is about 40 miles south of Sioux City.

title: Lewis and Clark State Recreation Site
listingDescription: Located at the western gateway of the Columbia River Gorge, Lewis & Clark State Park appropriately honors its legendary namesakes who camped and explored here in November, 1805. The park is situated near the mouth of the Sandy River where it spills into the mighty Columbia River and at one of the entrances to the Historic Columbia River Highway. A flat, grassy, tree-dotted park invites blankets and sun-lovers to come spend a leisurely day.

images.credit: "Century-old Sandy River Bridge" by kyle.anderson2 is licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 2.0
images.altText: An old railway bridge stretches across a river while swimmers frolic below
images.title: Sandy River Bridge
images.caption: The Sandy River Bridge can be seen from the park.

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Located at the western gateway of the Columbia River Gorge, Lewis & Clark State Park appropriately honors its legendary namesakes who camped and explored here in November, 1805. The park is situated near the mouth of the Sandy River where it spills into the mighty Columbia River and at one of the entrances to the Historic Columbia River Highway. A flat, grassy, tree-dotted park invites blankets and sun-lovers to come spend a leisurely day.

One of the most popular swimming spots on the Sandy River is adjacent to the park, as well as a public boat launch. A trail climbs the cliffs to Broughton’s Bluff, which serves as a geologic boundary between the foothills of the Cascade Mountain Range and the neighboring Willamette Valley to the west. This 160′ high series of cliffs provides excellent year-round rock climbing.
audioDescription: Flat, grassy, tree-dotted park near the mouth of the Sandy River. Picnic tables, benches, boat launch.

title: Lewis and Clark Trail Cycle Route
listingDescription: The Lewis & Clark Bicycle Trail was created to celebrate the anniversary of the Corps of Discovery’s 1803-1806 historic journey and offers cyclists the opportunity to follow the path of the intrepid explorers Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark. The main route of the Lewis & Clark Bicycle Trail is made up of paved roads, bike paths, and unpaved rail-trails, with occasional short sections of gravel roads. Conditions vary from rural to urban.
tags: lewis and clark national historic trail

Conditions vary from rural to urban.  Learn more >

title: Lewis and Clark Visitor Center
listingDescription: Operated by the Army Corps of Engineers, this visitor center includes exhibits and information on the Missouri River basin. It is located on Calumet Bluff just downstream from the Gavins Point Dam in Nebraska.

images.altText: Lewis and Clark Visitor Center overlooking the Missouri River. Circular drive featuring plants.
images.title: Lewis and Clark Visitor Center USACE
images.caption: U.S. Army Corps of Engineers Lewis and Clark Visitor Center

bodyText:
Operated by the Army Corps of Engineers, this visitor center includes exhibits and information on the Missouri River basin. It is located on Calumet Bluff just downstream from the Gavins Point Dam in Nebraska. To get there take Nebraska Highway 121 (road is closed until spring of 2020 due to bridge work), about 4 miles west of Yankton, South Dakota or South Dakota Highway 52 from Yankton to Crest Road. Hours of Operation: Open 7 days a week: 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. during the warm season; beginning Labor Day, the visitor center will be open Friday - Monday from 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. Closed on Federal Holidays.
For additional information call: 402-667-2546

Note: Please check current operation hours in response to COVID-19. Questions can be directed to the Lewis and Clark Visitor Center at  402-667-2546.
The visitor center includes various exhibts that showcase information and displays about the development of the entire Missouri River Basin. In addition, there are also information and displays about the geology, exploration, early navigation, settlement and natural history of the Missouri River region. The Calumet Bluff Theater programs highlight construction of Gavins Point Dam, the Lewis and Clark Expedition, wildflowers and the Missouri National Recreational River of Change film. The visitor center also has a bookstore. 

Directions to the Lewis and Clark Visitor Center
This is one of the the main public contact points for the park.
Located at 55245 Nebraska Highway 121, Crofton, NE 68730 Map

  • From US 81 in South Dakota: Cross the Missouri River on US 81 South. After 2 miles turn right (heading west) onto Nebraska Route 121. Continue on 121, following it to the left after 4 miles and drive to the top of the hill. The visitor center parking lot entrance is on the right. Or
  • From US 81 in Nebraska: Drive north on US 81 toward Yankton. Turn left onto Nebraska Route 121, following it to the left after 4 miles and drive to the top of the hill. The visitor center parking lot entrance is on the right.
  • From Yankton: Take South Dakota Route 52 west from Yankton six miles to the road that crosses the dam (Crest Road). Turn left onto the Crest Road (heading south). Follow this road across the dam and take the first road to the right, Nebraska Route 121. Turn right and drive up the hill. The visitor center parking lot entrance is on the right.
audioDescription: This center is perched above Gavins Point Dam, atop Calumet Bluff, just downstream from the Gavins Point Powerplant in the chalkstone-lined valley of the Missouri River.

title: Lewis in Steubenville
listingDescription: Meriwether Lewis stopped in Steubenville in 1803 while he headed west and wrote approvingly of the American settlements that had recently displaced Shawnee and Delaware communities.

images.credit: John Filson, "A Map of Kentucky" (London: J. Stockade, 1793).
images.altText: Black-and-white historic map depicting towns, waterways, and some minimal topography.
images.title: 1793 Map
images.caption: This 1793 map shows Delaware and Shawnee towns along the Ohio River.

tags: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail
bodyText:
“Stewbenville a small town situated on the Ohio in the state of Ohio about six miles above Charlestown in Virginia and 24 above Wheeling—is small well built thriving place  has several respectable families residing in it, five years since it was a wilderness”—Meriwether Lewis, September 6, 1803 

On this date, Meriwether Lewis and his small crew arrived at the American town of Steubenville.  

There had been an American fort at the site, Fort Steuben, built in 1787. It was named after Baron Von Steuben, the Prussian military leader who helped American troops during the American Revolutionary War.31 Von Steuben wrote Regulations for the Order and Discipline of the Troops of the United States, which was the U.S. military’s conduct manual at the time of the Lewis and Clark Expedition. 

The fort burned down in 1790, and by 1797, settlers formed a small village near the site of the fort. In 1803, Ohio was admitted to the union as a new state. 

“Five years since wilderness.” Lewis meant that it had been five years since White American settlers started coming here. Black families, who were enslaved by the White families, were often forced to join them. Many Shawnee, Delaware, Haudenosaunee, and Cherokee people lived in the multicultural Ohio River Valley, as did folks of French, Spanish, and African descent. It was a place of commerce, a bustling highway full of traders and travelers. If a wilderness was a place with no humans, this was far from that.  

For Lewis and others of his background in that era, “wilderness” meant any place without European-style settlements.  

Steubenville was one link in the chain of America’s westward expansion.
audioDescription: Historic wooden buildings with wood-shingled roofs are arranged in a square formation with a central courtyard, covered in grass. A fenced-in area lies in the middle of the grass. In the distance, treed hills rise from the Ohio River Valley.

title: Lewis’s Departure from Pittsburgh
listingDescription: Meriwether Lewis started his journey in Pittsburgh: he ordered a keelboat be made, recruited several men, and purchased and organized supplies for the long journey ahead.

images.credit: Senator John Heinz History Center
images.altText: Drawing of the city of Pittsburgh from 1817.
images.title: City of Pittsburgh, 1817
images.caption: Drawing of the city of Pittsburgh from 1817.

tags: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail
bodyText:
The point where the Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers meet to form the Ohio River has been a meeting point and site of commerce and conflict for thousands of years. Delaware, Shawnee, Haudenosaunee, and many other people frequently took boats from here to the Mississippi River, or even all the way to the Gulf of Mexico.  

By 1800, Pittsburgh was populated by European-American settlers and was known for its boat-building industry.

Meriwether Lewis was familiar with this place: he had been stationed here two years earlier at Fort Fayette, an American fort that served as a supply depot for other forts on the Ohio. Lewis ordered goods for the expedition to be shipped here.

Lewis needed a boat that could take him upstream—he knew they’d be navigating the Missouri River against the current.  

Canoes, dugout boats, and bateaux (flat-bottomed, lightweight riverboats) had long been used to transport materials up or down the river, but they had limited cargo capacity. Keelboats—in heavy use by the 1790s—could transport forty to fifty tons of material upriver quickly due to their long, narrow shape, heavy wooden keel, and pointed prow. Men used iron-tipped poles to push against the river bottom and cajole the boat upstream. 

When Lewis arrived at Fort Fayette on the afternoon of July 15, 1803, he saw only the skeleton of the fifty-five-foot keelboat that was supposed to be ready for him. And the boat builder was drunk.

Lewis waited six weeks for the boat to be ready. While he waited, Lewis prepared for the journey. He recruited new crew members.

He waited to hear back from William Clark, whom he asked to join him as co-commander of the expedition.  

He also worried. The water level dropped as the summer wore on. Would there be enough clearance or current for the boat to move easily down river?

He paid a river pilot, T. Moore, to get the boat and crew to the Falls of the Ohio River.

As soon as the boat was ready—August 30, 1803—they hopped on board and set off. 

About this article: This article is part of a series called “Pivotal Places: Stories from the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail.”
audioDescription: A grassy park on the point where the Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers come together to form the Ohio River. The riverbanks converge so that facing west, the river is visible, along with steep banks with city infrastructure built up on them. Facing east is downtown Pittsburgh and the many bridges crossing the Monongahela and Allegheny Rivers to access it.
managedByOrg: Commonwealth of Pennsylvania’s Department of Conservation and Natural Resources

title: Lewis’s Return Trip, shot by Pierre Cruzatte
listingDescription: Pierre Cruzatte accidentally shot Meriwether Lewis near here, mistaking him for an elk.

images.credit: Knowsley, Gleanings from the menagerie and aviary at Knowsley Hall Knowsley, 1846
images.altText: line drawing of an elk
images.title: Elk Illustration
images.caption: In 1806, Pierre Cruzatte mistook Meriwether Lewis for an Elk and accidentally shot him.

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
On a hunting excursion on August 11, 1806, Meriwether Lewis was shot through the hip by one of his crew members.  

The man who likely shot him was Pierre Cruzatte. Pierre, or “Peter,” as some of his English-speaking comrades called him, was from the lower Missouri River region. His father was French-Canadian and his mother was Omaha. He spoke French, Omaha, English, and other languages. He was a gifted fiddle player. He was also skilled at navigating boats through difficult river waters. 

Cruzatte was blind in one eye and near-sighted in the other. This may have explained why he was suspected of accidentally shooting Lewis: perhaps he mistook Lewis, who was dressed in elkskins, for an elk.  

“I called out to him damn you, you have shot me,” Lewis wrote that night. “and looked towards the place from whence the ball had come, seeing nothing I called Cruzatte several times as loud as I could but received no answer.” 

Cruzatte almost certainly did not intend to shoot Lewis. But other crew members present on the excursion that day concluded that, yes, the bullet had likely came from Cruzatte’s gun.

Sergeant Patrick Gass helped Lewis clean the wound and treat it with Peruvian bark. Lewis rested a few days, but the wound took several weeks to heal.  

This was the only confirmed instance when a member of the expedition was mistaken for an elk.  

About this article: This article is part of a series called “Pivotal Places: Stories from the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail.”

title: Lillian Pitt Public Artwork Land Overlook at Land Bridge
listingDescription: The Land Bridge on the Columbia River features three overlooks across spectacular vistas of land, river, and ocean. The site was built to honor the Chinookan people, who lived and traded along the Columbia River. Artwork at these overlooks honor the traditions of these people and tell the story of river, land and people along.

images.credit: "Land Bridge with Fort Vancouver" by dalechumbley is licensed under CC BY-NC-ND 2.0
images.altText: Metal panels with various geometric and animal cutouts inspired by Native American petroglyphs
images.title: Land Overlook at Land Bridge
images.caption: Lillian Pitt's Land Overlook

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
The Land Bridge on the Columbia River features three overlooks across spectacular vistas of land, river, and ocean. The site was built to honor the Chinookan people, who lived and traded along the Columbia River. Artwork at these overlooks honor the traditions of these people and tell the story of river, land and people along.

At the Land Overlook, “Spirit Baskets” by Lillian Pitt, feature figures inspired by Columbia River petroglyphs. The words for River, Land, and People appear in nine native languages on stainless steel panels “The images in this section are all cut out of the metal. We had to be really careful in how the metal was fabricated and finished so that little kids wouldn’t put their fingers in the holes and cut themselves. But we wanted the images to be cut out because the shadows that they throw are just as important as the images themselves. I think of them as ‘Shadow Spirits.’”

Lillian Pitt is a Pacific Northwest Native American artist. She was born and raised on the Warm Springs reservation in Oregon and her ancestors lived in and near the Columbia River Gorge for over 10,000 years. The focus of her work is on creating contemporary fine art pieces that delight today’s art lovers, and at the same time, honor the history and legends of her people.

For more information about Lillian Pitt’s work and a list of her other public art pieces to view in the area, please visit http://lillianpitt.com.
audioDescription: Metal panels with various geometric and animal cutouts inspired by Native American petroglypsh. These sit on four quarter-circle cement benches that form a full circle. Around them, a taller yellow cement wall has the names of local tribes etched into them. Interpretive panels sit atop these. All of this is underneath a circular slatted-roof-style pavilion.

title: Lillian Pitt Public Artwork: Honoring our Salmon at Ainsworth Greenspace
listingDescription: Three twelve-foot-tall sculptures topped with bronze totem heads, each one representing a being from native american legend. The sculptures face inward toward each other, forming a small plaza between them. A river-like pathway with a bronze spiral inset is in the center.

images.credit: "River Spirits" by brx0 is licensed under CC BY-SA 2.0
images.altText: Three statues from native legend look towards each other
images.title: Lillian Pitt Honoring Our Salmon
images.caption: The sculptures are inspired by local trees.

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Twelve-foot-tall sculptures inspired by trees of nearby forests complete a series of totem poles in Ainsworth Greenspace. Bronze totem heads representing legendary or sacred beings sit atop the three totems: “She Who Watches” by Lillian Pitt, “Salmon” by Ken MacKintosh, and “Crow” by Rick Bartow. The sculptures face inward, forming a small plaza with a river-like pathway with a bronze spiral inset in the center.

Describing the artwork, Lillian Pitt states, “We wanted to do something that was in keeping with the diverse neighborhoods that were nearby, and we wanted to do something to honor the maple trees that used to grow on that spot. We ended up using legendary images from different tribal traditions to represent the diversity in Native American culture, and we placed these giant images on top of pillars in the shape of maple tree trunks.”

The educational aspect of the Ainsworth project was enhanced by including a poetry project for students at the Ockley Green Middle School . Students learned to write poetry, and in keeping with the aims of the greenspace goals, were inspired to write about nature. The class was taught by collaborating artist and author, Gail Tremblay, who has worked frequently with Lillian over the years. Many of the resulting children’s poems are engraved onto the maple-tree columns that serve as the stands for the totems.

Lillian Pitt is a Pacific Northwest Native American artist. She was born and raised on the Warm Springs reservation in Oregon and her ancestors lived in and near the Columbia River Gorge for over 10,000 years. The focus of her work is on creating contemporary fine art pieces that delight today’s art lovers, and at the same time, honor the history and legends of her people.

For more information about Lillian Pitt’s work and a list of her other public art pieces to view in the area, please visit http://lillianpitt.com.
audioDescription: Three twelve-foot-tall sculptures topped with bronze totem heads, each one representing a being from native american legend. The sculptures face inward toward each other, forming a small plaza between them. A river-like pathway with a bronze spiral inset is in the center.

title: Lillian Pitt Public Artwork: River Guardian on the Willamette River
listingDescription: With a headdress of steel adorning her lead crystal glass head, and a body constructed of both copper and steel, River Guardian stands nine-feet tall along the banks of the Willamette River at the South Waterfront in Portland, Oregon. She watches with two faces: one looking toward the river, and one looking in the opposite direction, signifying her protection of people on both water and land.
tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
With a headdress of steel adorning her lead crystal glass head, and a body constructed of both copper and steel, River Guardian stands nine-feet tall along the banks of the Willamette River at the South Waterfront in Portland, Oregon. She watches with two faces: one looking toward the river, and one looking in the opposite direction, signifying her protection of people on both water and land. This public art installation is the result of a collaboration between Lillian Pitt and Mikkel Hilde. The artwork was commissioned through a joint effort between the Portland State University Native American community and Portland City Parks.

Lillian Pitt is a Pacific Northwest Native American artist. She was born and raised on the Warm Springs reservation in Oregon and her ancestors lived in and near the Columbia River Gorge for over 10,000 years. The focus of her work is on creating contemporary fine art pieces that delight today’s art lovers, and at the same time, honor the history and legends of her people.

“I have a very strong commitment to helping in any way that I can when it comes to shining a light on the cultures of river people. That’s because my ancestors all lived along the Columbia River, and depended largely on fishing for their livelihood. So I was thrilled to be able to bring River Guardian to the South Waterfront.”

For more information about Lillian Pitt’s work and a list of her other public art pieces to view in the area, please visit http://lillianpitt.com.
audioDescription: A nine-foot-tall statue on the banks of the Willamette River made of steel, copper, and glass. The body is made of copper and steel, while the head is circular and made of lead crystal glass. The head is set in an abstract steel headdress.

title: Lillian Pitt Public Artwork: Rosa Parks Station
listingDescription: The art project at the Rosa Parks station was completed by a team including Native American artist Lillian Pitt, Ken MacKintosh, Rick Bartow, Elizabeth Woody, and Gail Tremblay. The artists used traditional motifs to symbolize the life-sustaining relationships of nature. Pitt served as team leader of five members to complete her vision.

images.credit: "Rosa Parks Station" by TriMet is licensed under CC BY 2.0
images.altText: Native American symbols adorn columns, railway panels and benches
images.title: Rosa Parks Station
images.caption: Rosa Parks Station

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Portland’s public transit system offers travelers a unique, rich emersion into the local art scene. The Tri-County Metropolitan Transportation District of Oregon (Tri-Met) promotes transit use and community pride by integrating permanent and temporary art works that celebrate the contributions of the cultural richness in the region.

The art project at the Rosa Parks station was completed by a team including Native American artist Lillian Pitt, Ken MacKintosh, Rick Bartow, Elizabeth Woody, and Gail Tremblay. The artists used traditional motifs to symbolize the life-sustaining relationships of nature. Pitt served as team leader of five members to complete her vision. She states, “The Interstate project was the first public art project I worked on. At the time, there was not one public art project in Portland that was done by a Native American artist. So I thought, that’s not right, and I went ahead and applied for the job.”

Artistic interpretations of historic petroglyphs from the Columbia River Gorge appear on columns, custom benches, and railing panels. A traditional basket weave pattern is repeated in the pavement. And, at the ends of each of the shelters near the apex of the roofline, are sculptured images of birds, fishing apparatus and other symbols of cultural significance. “I designed the bricks into a basket design, the fence railings and the gable ends,” states Pitt.

Pitt’s artwork along the Tri-Met has become known for an iconography rooted in the Columbia River petroglyphs of her ancestors. Through her use of this and other petroglyph symbols, Pitt has helped to bring the Indigenous iconography of the Columbia River to the public eye and affirm the ancient as well as contemporary Indigenous presence in the region.

Lillian Pitt is a Pacific Northwest Native American artist. She was born and raised on the Warm Springs reservation in Oregon and her ancestors lived in and near the Columbia River Gorge for over 10,000 years. The focus of her work is on creating contemporary fine art pieces that delight today’s art lovers, and at the same time, honor the history and legends of her people.

For more information about Lillian Pitt’s work and a list of her other public art pieces to view in the area, please visit http://lillianpitt.com.

More information about artwork along the Tri-Met can be found here: https://trimet.org/publicart/index.htm
audioDescription: Traditional Native American motifs based on artistic interpretations of petroglyphs from the Columbia River symbolizing the life-sustaining relationships of nature adorn columns, benches, and railing panels at this transit station.

title: Lillian Pitt Public Artwork: The Welcome Gate at Land Bridge
listingDescription: Two cedar logs topped with crossed canoe paddles with a cast-glass sculpture of a Chinook woman’s face greet visitors to the Land Bridge, a historic tribal crossroads and a historic point of contact between European and Native people on the Columbia River. The Welcome Gate by artist Lillian Pitt represents how Chinook people welcomed someone arriving by canoe and serves as a fitting entry to the Vancouver Land Bridge.

images.credit: "Land Bridge Entry" by Matthew Warner is licensed under CC BY-NC 2.0
images.altText: Two canoe paddles with a glass Chinook woman's face sti atop two poles
images.title: Welcome Gate at Land Bridge
images.caption: Lillian Pitt's Welcome Gate

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Two cedar logs topped with crossed canoe paddles with a cast-glass sculpture of a Chinook woman’s face greet visitors to the Land Bridge, a historic tribal crossroads and a historic point of contact between European and Native people on the Columbia River. The Welcome Gate by artist Lillian Pitt represents how Chinook people welcomed someone arriving by canoe and serves as a fitting entry to the Vancouver Land Bridge (Link: https://nativeamerica.travel/listings/confluence-land-bridge-in-vancouver).

At this location, the Hudson’s Bay Company stood as the first European trading post in the Pacific Northwest, and Lewis and Clark camped at this site during their expedition. Fort Vancouver was built twenty years later.

“The Land Bridge is a real link connecting back to the Klickitat Trail, Lewis and Clark, and the development of the Northwest. It completes a circle that’s been broken,” states Johnpaul Jones, acclaimed Native American architect and landscape architect who worked on the project along with designer Maya Lin.

The Welcome Gate is the perfect creative entryway to the Land Bridge, which tells the story of river, land and people along the Columbia River. Artist Lillian Pitt states, “The site was built to honor the Chinookan people, who were awesome traders. They lived and traded from the mouth of the Columbia River in Astoria, all the way upriver to the area where my ancestors lived at Celilo. And this area they established within modern-day Vancouver was a major gathering place for them . . . and so it was here that they welcomed many people to trade.”

About the author: Lillian Pitt is a Pacific Northwest Native American artist. She was born and raised on the Warm Springs reservation in Oregon and her ancestors lived in and near the Columbia River Gorge for over 10,000 years. The focus of her work is on creating contemporary fine art pieces that delight today’s art lovers, and at the same time, honor the history and legends of her people.

For more information about Lillian Pitt’s work and a list of her other public art pieces to view in the area, please visit http://lillianpitt.com.
audioDescription: Two cedar logs topped with crossed canoe paddles with a cast-glass sculpture of a Chinook woman’s face. Side cement path lined with landscaped trees and lights.

title: Lillian Pitt Public Artwork: “Voices,” at the Oregon Convention Center
listingDescription: Lillian Pitt’s “Voices” is a series of twenty six bronze relief plaques located in the Oregon Convention Center and are part of the Center’s Public Art project. Her work is the largest collection of public art by a Native American artist in any public space within the City of Portland. Ten artists were selected through a public invitation process to produce work for the center’s permanent collection, one of the most varied convention center art programs in the country.

images.credit: "Oregon Convention Center" by sd is licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 2.0
images.altText: A large circular modern building with two glass spires rising from the roof
images.title: Oregon Convention Center
images.caption: The Oregon Convention Center

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Lillian Pitt’s “Voices” is a series of twenty six bronze relief plaques located in the Oregon Convention Center and are part of the Center’s Public Art project. Her work is the largest collection of public art by a Native American artist in any public space within the City of Portland. Ten artists were selected through a public invitation process to produce work for the center’s permanent collection, one of the most varied convention center art programs in the country.

The twenty-six plaques in the exhibit represent the voices of Native people throughout the region. Lillian is a descendent of Wasco, Yakama and Warm Springs ancestors, and she felt it was her obligation to honor all of the Native peoples of the region in her work.

Lillian states, “My goal wasn’t just to produce public art but to educate viewers about the rich cultures and history of the various Native peoples who lived throughout Oregon.” She further states, “We titled the work “Voices” because we thought of the plaques as giving our ancestors a voice … giving them an opportunity to be heard in this modern world where the memory of them is otherwise being drowned by progress.”

Lillian Pitt is a Pacific Northwest Native American artist. She was born and raised on the Warm Springs reservation in Oregon and her ancestors lived in and near the Columbia River Gorge for over 10,000 years. The focus of her work is on creating contemporary fine art pieces that delight today’s art lovers, and at the same time, honor the history and legends of her people.

For more information about Lillian Pitt’s work and a list of her other public art pieces to view in the area, please visit http://lillianpitt.com.
audioDescription: Paved city street, circular tan building, blue glass spires rise from the roof. Two flag poles stand on either side of the sidewalk leading to the entrance.

title: Little Sioux, Iowa
listingDescription: Located at the foot of the Loess Hills State Forest, Little Sioux boasts panoramic views of the Missouri River Valley that Lewis and Clark traveled. Nearby Larpenteur Memorial Road, named for early settler and French fur trader Charles Larpenteur, winds along the base of the Loess Hills just outside of town.
tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Located at the foot of the Loess Hills State Forest, Little Sioux boasts panoramic views of the Missouri River Valley that Lewis and Clark traveled. Nearby Larpenteur Memorial Road, named for early settler and French fur trader Charles Larpenteur, winds along the base of the Loess Hills just outside of town. Little Sioux is also home to Murray Hall, which is listed on the National Register of Historic Places and named after Michael Murray, a mercantile business owner from the early history of Little Sioux. Originally a general store and now a museum and reception space, Murray Hall was built in 1877 and is a rare example of the two-story “false front” commercial building style. The Little Sioux Scout Ranch of the Boy Scouts of America is located in Little Sioux.

The annual Little Sioux Homecoming is the perfect family event with a parade, carnival, dance, and barbecue held on the fourth weekend in August. Little Sioux is also a stop on the 29-mile Embrace the Hills annual bike ride. With 3,835 acres of Loess Hills State Forest nearby, Little Sioux is the ideal stop for any nature-lover.

If hunting or hiking attract you, the six nature areas located near Little Sioux are perfect for you. Gee-Hruska Wetland Area is a 30-acre preserve where waterfowl, pheasant, and quail are frequently found. Located just one mile south of Little Sioux, Gee-Hruska is accessed through the O’Day Wetland Area. With 165 acres of woodland with ridge-top native prairie stands and trails, the Gleason-Hubel Wildlife Area is good hunting ground for turkey, deer, quail, squirrels, and rabbits. The perfect place for bird-watching and morel mushroom hunting, this Wildlife Area is just one mile southeast of the town center.

For the avid fisherman, the Sioux Dam Wildlife Area offers bank fishing along the Little Sioux River. Sioux Dam is only four miles north and holds 10 acres of prairie and woodland hunting. Finally, the Murray Hill Scenic Overlook is a high elevation point that features a hiking trail to the top of the ridge for a panoramic view of the Missouri River Valley. The steep climb to the top offers a picturesque view of the surrounding area and is just 2.4 miles northeast of Little Sioux.

No matter what your interest – historic or outdoors – Little Sioux is sure to have something to share with our visitors!
audioDescription: small town residential areas and business district. Tree-lined streets, wetlands, Missouri River Valley, rolling hills, hiking trails, city parks.

title: Locust Grove
listingDescription: Locust Grove was built around 1790 by Major William Croghan and his wife, Lucy Clark Croghan in Louisville, Kentucky. Lucy was William Clark’s sister. Locust Grove was visited by a number of national figures, including James Monroe, Andrew Jackson, Zachary Taylor, John James Audubon, and Aaron Burr.

images.credit: Historic American Building Survey
images.altText: black and white photo of locust grove esterior
images.caption: Locust Grove in Louisville, Kentucky

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Locust Grove was built around 1790 by Major William Croghan and his wife, Lucy Clark Croghan in Louisville, Kentucky. Lucy was William Clark’s sister. Locust Grove was visited by a number of national figures, including James Monroe, Andrew Jackson, Zachary Taylor, John James Audubon, and Aaron Burr.

 

Architecturally, Locust Grove is a fine example of the frontier's adaptation of Georgian styling. Each floor of the two and one-half story brick residence contains four rooms divided by an axis hallway. A kitchen, servants quarters, well, dairy and log cabin have been rebuilt on excavated foundations.

 

On November 9, 1806, Lewis and Clark stopped at Locust Grove on their way back to St. Louis. The citizens of Louisville threw a banquet ball and lit bonfires in their honor. On November 13, 1806, Lewis and Clark parted - Lewis went to Monticello to see President Jefferson and Clark went to Fincastle, Virginia.
audioDescription: 2 ½ story brick house with a large white front porch with an overhang. Small staircase leads up to the porch and front door. Four chimneys, two on each farthest most end of the house. Five windows on the top floor are evenly spaced, and four on the bottom, two on each side of the door. There are four rooms split up by an axis hall.

title: Locust Grove, Kentucky
listingDescription: Lewis and Clark visited Locust Grove, the home of Clark’s sister and brother-in-law, at the end of their journey.

images.credit: Jared Brooks, "A map of the rapids of the Ohio River and of the countries on each side thereof"
images.altText: Drawing of the town as Louisville as viewed from across the Ohio River.
images.title: Map of Louisville 1806
images.caption: 1806 engraving of the new American settlement Louisville, as viewed from Clarksville.

tags: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail
bodyText:
William Clark’s sister and brother-in-law, Lucy Clark Croghan and William Croghan, built a house outside of Louisville around 1790. They named it Locust Grove, after the trees that grew nearby. The Clark-Croghans were wealthy and well-connected. Visitors to their house included James Monroe, Aaron Burr, and John J. Audubon. Many people lived at Locust Grove, as the Croghans enslaved about thirty-five individuals of African descent. These enslaved people built the estate’s houses and other buildings, did all the farming, and performed other labor as demanded by the Clark-Croghans. 

William Clark and York grew up at nearby Mulberry Hill. This plantation was built and run by people enslaved by the Clarks—including York’s parents.

Clark and Meriwether Lewis left the Louisville area in 1803. They were gone for three years. No one knew if they were still alive or how the journey had gone. 

When they finally arrived back in Louisville in 1806, Clark invited Lewis to stay with him at his sister’s home to rest and recuperate. They spent three weeks there. Settlers in Louisville had a party to welcome them back. York’s wife and family were surely happy to have him home, but their reunion was not recorded by local newspapers.  

What had changed in Louisville while they were gone? 

More American settlers farmed on the lands around Louisville—lands that until recently, Indigenous families had called home. There were likely more Black people in the area, since White settlers who moved here (like the Clarks) brought with them the people they enslaved.  

The hard work of these enslaved individuals meant that the ports of Louisville were probably bustling even more—more goods to trade up and down the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers, from Pittsburgh down to New Orleans.  

Would it have felt differently to Lewis, Clark, and York? 

About this article: This article is part of a series called “Pivotal Places: Stories from the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail.”
audioDescription: The main house is two stories with a pitched roof. It is made of brick, has a front porch with a covering, many windows on both floors, and three chimneys. Two stone outbuildings sit to the right of the house. The house has a large lawn in front and trees behind it.

quickFacts.value: William Clark’s sister, brother-in-law, and older brother lived at Locust Grove. Clark and Meriwether Lewis stopped at Locust Grove on their journey west and on their return home.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail, National Historic Landmark
quickFacts.name: Designation

title: Lolo Pass Visitor Center
listingDescription: The Lolo Pass Visitor Center is a historical landmark site on the Lewis and Clark Highway, bordering Montana and Idaho. It is located near the area where Meriwether Lewis and William Clark took eleven days in September of 1805 to traverse the grueling Lolo Pass through the Bitterroot Mountains.

images.credit: "Lolo Pass Montana2" by D Guisinger is licensed under CC BY 2.0
images.altText: A rustic log building is flanked by deciduous trees and a flagpole
images.title: Lolo Pass Visitor Center
images.caption: The Lolo Pass Visitor Center

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
The Lolo Pass Visitor Center is a historical landmark site on the Lewis and Clark Highway, bordering Montana and Idaho. It is located near the area where Meriwether Lewis and William Clark took eleven days in September of 1805 to traverse the grueling Lolo Pass through the Bitterroot Mountains. The dangerous terrain, harsh weather conditions, and near-starvation resulted in the most arduous portion of the entire expedition in which the men resorted to eating some of their own horses to survive. The visitor center is also located on the Nez Perce National Historic Trail, a path followed by a band of Nez Perce Indians while fleeing from the U.S. Calvary in 1877 to avoid being forced onto a reservation. 

At the visitor center, visitors will find information detailing Lewis and Clark's journey across the Bitterroot Mountains and the flight of the Nez Perce Indians, along with other historical, natural, and general information. As a major trailhead for cross-country skiing and snowmobiling, the center also has a warming hut for skiers and recreationists, a 24-hour restroom, a snowmobile parking log, and maps and information pertinent to winter visitors.

For more information or current Lolo Pass conditions, visit Nez Perce-Clearwater National Forests - Lolo Pass Visitor Center (usda.gov) or call (208) 942-3113.
audioDescription: The visitor center is rustic building composed of brown logs built in the style of a log cabin. It is flanked by small deciduous trees, and a flagpole stands on the front left side of the building. A paved driveway runs in front of the visitor center. Behind it, the slope of a pine tree-covered moutain side rises.
passportStampLocationDescription: Stamp located in visitor center.

title: Lolo Trail
listingDescription: In mid-September 1805, the Lewis and Clark Expedition reached the historic Lolo Trail. The Corps knew the Lolo Trail would provide them a physical challenge, and they feared they would not survive the peaks without assistance. They were able to acquire as many horses as possible and enlist the help of a few guides who knew the route that lay ahead. Under the guidance of Old Toby (Shoshone), the Corps turned northward and began their ascent into the Bitterroot Mountains.

images.credit: Photo by G Thomas
images.altText: view of the bitterroot mountains
images.caption: View of the Bitterroot Mountain Range in Montana and Idaho

bodyText:
In mid-September 1805, the Lewis and Clark Expedition reached the historic Lolo Trail. The Corps knew the Lolo Trail would provide them a physical challenge, and they feared they would not survive the peaks without assistance. They were able to acquire as many horses as possible and enlist the help of a few guides who knew the route that lay ahead. Under the guidance of Old Toby (Shoshone), the Corps turned northward and began their ascent into the Bitterroot Mountains.

 

Over the course of 11 days they walked a 200-mile stretch of mountain terrain. They suffered from frostbite, malnutrition and dehydration. Clark noted, "I have been wet and as cold in every part as I ever was in my life, indeed I was at one time fearfull my feet would freeze in the thin Mockirsons which I wore" (DeVoto 1997, 240). They pushed forward, nearing the end of the Trail. Capturing the moment, Lewis wrote:

 

“. . . the pleasure I now felt in having tryumphed over the rockey Mountains and decending once more to a level and fertile country where there was every rational hope of finding a comfortable subsistence for myself and party can be more readily conceived than expressed, nor was the flattering prospect of the final success of the expedition less pleasing . . .”

 

Exhausted and starving, the men stumbled out of the Bitterroot Mountains and encountered the Nez Perce Indians at Weippe Prairie. On their return trip, the Corps of Discovery again traversed the Lolo Trail - this time taking 15 days.
audioDescription: The Lolo Trail sprawls along the Bitterroot Mountain Range of the Rocky Mountains from Lolo Montana to Weippe Prairie Idaho. Large snow-capped mountain tops and canyons are visible while on the trails as far as the eyes can see. Large, dense patches and meadows of pine trees, sometimes also snow-capped, are visible along the trail as well.
